[[Ford Crown Victoria]] ''(unofficial)'' | successor = [[Ford Taurus (fifth generation)]] }} The '''Ford Five Hundred''' is a [[Full-size car|full-size automobile]]{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/ford/five-hundred/2005/features-specs.html?sub=sedan |title=2005 Ford Five Hundred SE Sedan 3.0L V6 6-speed Automatic Features and Specs |publisher=Edmunds.com |date=2010-03-10 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} that was manufactured and marketed by [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] from 2005 to 2007. Deriving its nameplate from the ''500" suffix used by Ford on the Custom 500, [[Ford Fairlane (Americas)|Fairlane 500]] and [[Ford Galaxie|Galaxie 500]] model ranges from the 1950s to 1970s, the Five Hundred was the larger of two model lines intended to replace the [[Ford Taurus (fourth generation)|Ford Taurus]] (the [[Ford Fusion (Americas)|Ford Fusion]] being the smaller vehicle). Within the Ford model line, the Five Hundred was slotted between the Fusion and [[Ford Crown Victoria|Crown Victoria]]. Marking the debut of the Ford D3 platform, the Five Hundred marked several firsts for [[full-size Ford]] vehicles, introducing front-wheel drive, all-wheel drive (as an option), unibody construction, and the first generation sold without a V8 engine (since the Ford Model A). Along with the first completely new full-size chassis since 1979, the 2005 Five Hundred introduced two distinct full-size model lines to Ford (for the first time since the 1978 discontinuation of the Custom 500). The Five Hundred was produced exclusively as a four-door sedan, with the role of the Ford Taurus station wagon adopted by the [[Ford Freestyle]] (marketed as a CUV by Ford). The Five Hundred was marketed by Lincoln-Mercury under the revived [[Mercury Montego]] nameplate, slotted between the [[Mercury Milan]] and [[Mercury Grand Marquis]]. For the 2008 model year, for a mid-cycle revision, the Five Hundred was re-christened as the Ford Taurus; the Freestyle became the Taurus X, with the Mercury Montego renamed the Mercury Sable. Outside of North America and South Korea, the Five Hundred name remained in use through 2009. The Five Hundred was assembled by Ford at its [[Chicago Assembly]] facility ([[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]]) alongside the Freestyle and Montego. Excluding export sales, 241,402 Ford Five Hundreds were produced. == Background == [[File:Prodigy sm.jpg|thumb|left|2000 [[Ford Prodigy]] diesel-electric concept, which partly influenced the body design of the Five Hundred/Montego]]As part of the 1999 acquisition of [[Volvo Cars]] and its addition to [[Premier Automotive Group]], Ford Motor Company expanded on its [[vehicle safety technology]] capabilities and began development of a D186 Taurus replacement.{{cite web|url=http://www.web2carz.com/1967/2005/Ford/Five-Hundred/reviews/overview |title=Ford's Magic New Number |publisher=Larry Edsall, Web2cars |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120005556/http://www.web2carz.com/1967/2005/Ford/Five-Hundred/reviews/overview |archive-date=2008-11-20 |url-status=dead }}https://europe.autonews.com/node/334356/ In 2000, the [[Ford Prodigy]] concept car was shown. A 72MPG diesel-electric hybrid designed as part of the [[Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles]], the Prodigy would introduce much of the exterior styling of the Five Hundred; it was also the first Ford to use the horizontal "three-bar" grille (which made its production debut on the 2006 Ford Fusion). The Ford Five Hundred entered production on July 12, 2004{{cite book|title=Ward's Automotive Yearbook 2005|publisher=Ward's Communications, Inc|year=2005|page=112|editor=Binder, Alan K}} at [[Chicago Assembly]] (the previous assembly site of the [[Ford Taurus (fourth generation)|Ford Taurus]]), and became available to the public in September 2004. === Total Vehicle Geometry === The Ford Five Hundred/Mercury Montego were engineered with a quality control system named Total Vehicle Geometry (TVG).{{cite web|url=http://www.theautochannel.com/news/2004/02/07/179649.html|title=2005 Mercury Montego Introduced|publisher=The Auto Channel, February 7, 2004}} Designed by Volvo, TVG is heavily computer-based, allowing for designers, engineers, and suppliers access for all data and results related to prototypes at all stages of the design process. With improved participation and access, fit and finish increased on prototype parts, decreasing the time needed for preliminary production vehicles, so called ''pilot'' vehicles. == Overview == [[File:Ford Five Hundred (15308124146).jpg|thumb|Ford Five Hundred (rear 3/4)]]Noted for its simple, straight-forward styling, large interior cabin, prominent [[Greenhouse (automotive)|greenhouse]] and high [[H-point]] seating, the Five Hundred was designed by George Bucher, Chief Designer,{{cite web |title = Ford Five Hundred |publisher = Car Reviews and News |url = http://carreviewsandnews.com/detroitford500.html |access-date = 2015-04-03 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150409171216/http://carreviewsandnews.com/detroitford500.html |archive-date = 2015-04-09 |url-status = dead }}{{cite web | title = Fanfare for the Common Car | publisher = The New York Times, Phil Patton, April 11, 2004 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/11/automobiles/fanfare-for-the-common-car.html}} under the direction of Ford Vice President of Design, [[J Mays]].{{cite web | title = J Mays, Noted Ford Designer, to Retire | publisher = The New York Times, Phil Patton, November 5, 2013 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/06/automobiles/j-mays-noted-ford-designer-to-retire.html}} === Chassis === The Ford Five Hundred is based on the [[Ford D3 platform]], shared with the [[Mercury Montego]] and [[Ford Taurus X|Ford Freestyle]]. An evolution of the Volvo P2 platform (used in the [[Volvo S80#First generation|Volvo S80]]), the platform marked the shift to front-wheel drive in full-size Ford sedans; an electro-hydraulic [[Haldex]] all-wheel drive system (based on that used on the Volvo S80 and XC90) was optional in all versions of the Ford Five Hundred or Mercury Montego. Along with Haldex AWD, several Volvo design features were incorporated into the structure of the Five Hundred, including a modified version of [[Side Impact Protection System]] (SIPS) from Volvo, channeling impact forces around the passenger compartment; the front frame rails were redesigned to better absorb impact forces. Alongside standard dual front airbags, the Five Hundred was available with both side airbags and curtain airbags as an option. For the first time in a full-size Ford sedan, the Ford Five Hundred featured independent suspension for both front and rear axles, with [[MacPherson strut]] front suspension and a [[Multi-link suspension|multi-link rear axle]] with coilover shocks; both axles were fitted with stabilizer bars. As with the Ford Crown Victoria, the Five Hundred was configured with four-wheel anti-lock disc brakes (12.5-inch front, 13-inch rear). The Ford Five Hundred/Mercury Montego were powered by a single engine, shared with the Ford Taurus: a 203 hp 3.0L [[Ford Duratec engine#30|Duratec]] V6, paired with a 6-speed Aisin automatic transmission (for front-wheel drive versions) or a ZF CVT (for AWD). === Body === A distinguishing feature of the Ford Five Hundred is its tall exterior height; at 61.5 inches tall, it was over 5 inches taller than the Ford Taurus sold alongside it. A key feature driving the use of the tall body design was the upward movement of the [[H-point]] (hip point). As with the [[Ford Focus (first generation)|first-generation Ford Focus]], the seats of the Five Hundred were positioned relatively high from the floor, providing an upright seating position and improved visibility, access, and egress. In addition, the rear seat was positioned higher than the front seats. The Ford Five Hundred was the first full-size Ford sedan to feature a folding rear seat to supplement the 21 cubic foot trunk (larger than the Lincoln Town Car). With the option of a folding front passenger seat, a Five Hundred was able to carry objects up to ten feet long inside the vehicle. While visibility was one factor behind the higher seating position, safety was another as well. Derived from the Volvo [[Side Impact Protection System]] (SIPS), a [[Hydroforming|hydroformed]] cross-car steel beam underneath the front seats was welded between the B-pillars (directly below an identical beam above the B-pillars). George Bucher, Ford's chief designer said "it was a challenge to sculpt a Ford-styled body around a Volvo chassis, and added that designers used what he calls plainer surfaces with taut lines to give the car a modern look without losing its passenger-car proportions."{{cite web|url=http://cars.twincities.com/reviews/ford/five-hundred/2006|title=2006 Ford Five Hundred|publisher=Larry Edsall, Twincities.com}} === Trim === Three trim lines were offered: ''SE'', ''SEL'', and ''Limited''. An [[all wheel drive]] system was available across the range. Base prices start at [[USD|US$]]22,795 for a front-wheel drive ''SE'' and range to US$28,495 for an all-wheel drive ''Limited''. Interiors on SEL and Limited trim levels featured a new hydrographic system for applying wood appliqués.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/overview/ford_five-hundred_2005|title=2005 Ford Five Hundred - Review|date=January 4, 2004|publisher=The Car Connection|author=}} *''SE'' - Included: Cloth upholstery, power driver's seat, keyless entry, power accessory delay, power trunk release, power mirrors, power locks, power windows with automatic driver's side window, 17" painted alloy rims, an AM/FM stereo with single-CD player, body color mirrors and handles, and air conditioning. *''SEL'' - Added: heated mirrors, fog lamps, security alarm, automatic headlamps, automatic temp control, message center with compass, an AM/FM stereo with 6-disc in dash CD player with MP3 capability and steering wheel audio controls, power front seats, and an auto-dimming rear view mirror. *''Limited'' - Added: leather seats, heated seats, memory driver's seat and mirrors, an analog clock, an Audiophile sound system with a subwoofer and an AM/FM stereo with 6-disc in dash CD player and MP3 capability, chrome mirrors, and a trunk cargo net. === Revisions === During its production run, the Ford Five Hundred saw relatively few changes. For 2006, a new navigation radio made by Pioneer (featuring [[Sirius Satellite Radio]]) became an option; traction control was now changed to an option on front-wheel drive models (from standard). A mid-year running change removed the exterior doorside trim molding on all trim levels in favor of a small sill molding at the bottom edge of the door. The 2007 Five Hundred remained unchanged, with the SE model discontinued. All versions built after September 4, 2006 have side airbags as standard, along with curtain airbags (marketed as the ''Safety Canopy''). The powertrain warranty was revised to 5 years / {{convert|60000|mi|km|sing=on}}. A new Chrome Package became available, with 18-inch eight-spoke alloy wheels and a chrome trim mesh grille. == Discontinuation == {{wikinewsart|Ford Taurus to be revived}} [[File:Auto Show 032.jpg|thumb|2008 Ford Five Hundred concept. Upon direction of Ford CEO [[Alan Mulally]], this was renamed the Ford Taurus before its production]] The Five Hundred ended production on April 12, 2007, as did the Mercury Montego and Ford Freestyle.{{cite book|title=Ward's Automotive Yearbook 2008|publisher=Ward's Communications, Inc|year=2008|page=115|editor=Binder, Alan K}} For the [[North American International Auto Show#2007|2007 North American International Auto Show]], Ford introduced a mid-cycle 2008 update of the Five Hundred and Montego; the new sedans had front and rear fascia styling, new interiors, and new powertrains with a 263hp 3.5L V6 and a new 6-speed automatic transmission. Although the changes were positively received, Ford CEO [[Alan Mulally]] chose to rename all three D3 platform cars, with the Five Hundred and Montego becoming the fifth-generation Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable; the similarly updated Ford Freestyle continued as the Ford Taurus X. Although the Taurus had been out of retail markets since 2006 (the Sable, since 2005), Mullaly cited the larger brand familiarity of the Taurus/Sable nameplates as the reason for the renaming of the two D3 sedans. For the 2010 model year, the Ford Taurus underwent a complete redesign. Although retaining the D3 chassis, the exterior and interior was completely changed, to add more aggressive styling.{{cite journal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/automobiles/30DESIGN.html?_r=0|title=Designer’s Goal Was a Buff Bull|journal=The New York Times | first = Phil | last = Patton | date = August 28, 2009|quote=As he set out to restyle the (fifth generation Ford Taurus, a facelifted Five Hundred) for 2010, Earl Lucas, the car’s chief exterior designer, had a mission: to make the high-set sedan more macho and muscular.}} This became the final generation Taurus for North America. As the Mercury brand was being phased out in 2010, 2009 marked the final year of the Sable nameplate. == Sales == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Calendar Year ! American sales |- | 2004{{cite web|url=http://www.theautochannel.com/news/2006/01/04/204860.html |title=Ford Achieves First Car Sales Increase Since 1999 |publisher=Theautochannel.com |date=2004-11-17 |accessdate=2009-04-28}} | 14,106 |- | 2005 | 107,932 |- | 2006{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/article_download.cfm?article_id=27379 |title=Ford Motor Company 2007 sales |date=January 3, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212180838/http://media.ford.com/article_download.cfm?article_id=27379 |archivedate=2009-02-12 }} | 84,218 |- | 2007 | 35,146 |} == Variants == [[File:2004-2006 Mercury Montego.jpg|right|thumb|Mercury Montego]] [[File:05-07 Ford Freestyle SE.jpg|right|thumb|Ford Freestyle SE]] Alongside the Ford Five Hundred, several versions of the D3 platform were marketed by Ford Motor Company, with all variants produced in the same Chicago assembly facility. === Mercury Montego === The Mercury division sold the Ford Five Hundred as the Mercury Montego, slotted in between the Grand Marquis and the Milan (replacing the Sable). For the first time since 1979, Mercury sold a completely new full-size car (and two full-size Mercury sedans for the first time since 1974). While largely distinguished from the Five Hundred by its standard HID headlights and LED taillights (the largest set of LED taillights ever introduced on a Ford vehicle at the time), the Montego also differs from the Five Hundred in its monochomatic exterior, satin aluminum trim, and two-tone interior with black-toned wood trim. As with the Five Hundred, the Montego was produced in front and all-wheel drive configurations, sharing the same powertrains. In contrast, Mercury sold the Montego in two trim levels (Luxury and Premier). === Ford Freestyle === In its development as one of the vehicles to replace the Ford Taurus, the model lineup of the Five Hundred/Montego was reduced to the four-door sedan exclusively. While not deleted, the role of the Taurus/Sable station wagon would change as it was repackaged as a functionally similar [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]], replacing the long-running third-row jumpseat with a forward-facing folding third row. Slotted in between the [[Ford Explorer]] and [[Ford Expedition]] in its exterior footprint, the Ford Freestyle was fitted solely with a 3.0-liter [[V6 engine]] and a [[continuously variable transmission]] (CVT). In its exterior design, the Freestyle borrowed elements from several vehicles, including the Explorer and Escape. In place of the luxury sedan interior of the Five Hundred/Montego, the Freestyle was designed with a model-specific interior. While the Freestyle would serve as the basis for the [[Mercury Meta One]] concept vehicle, no Mercury version was ever produced beyond the prototype stage. ==Reception== During its production, the Ford Five Hundred would attract a high degree of attention by automotive industry critics over its controversial styling. Intended as "guilt-free luxury"{{cite web|url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/review/1005540_preview-2005-ford-five-hundred|title=2004 Detroit Auto Show Coverage: 2005 Ford Five Hundred|publisher=The Car Connection, (1/4/2004)}}, several reviewers have noted its close resemblance to Volkswagen and Audi sedans, (along with the lack of brand differentiation between the Ford Five Hundred and Mercury Montego).''{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/04/business/yourmoney/04ford.html?pagewanted=2|title=A Designer Lets Loose in the ’Year of the Car’|author=Danny Hakim|date=January 4, 2004|work=The New York Times}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/31/automobiles/31auto.html|title=2005 Ford Five Hundred: Mature Audiences Suggested|publisher=The New York Times, Christopher Jenson, October 31, 2004}}{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20041002/news_lz1d2ford.html|title=Ford Five Hundred called roomy inside, dull outside|publisher=Automotive News, Richard Truett, October 2, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150412080451/http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20041002/news_lz1d2ford.html|archivedate=April 12, 2015|url-status=dead}}'' Others criticized its conservative exterior styling, likely to only appeal to older buyers.{{cite web|url=http://forums.vwvortex.com/showthread.php?1726075-This-Guy-Must-Hate-Ford&p=17588653&viewfull=1|title=Are Ford designs boring?|publisher=The Detroit News, 12/19/04, Daniel Howes|quote=Is the Five Hundred boring? It looks a little too Teutonic, Mays admits. We've gone back. We've looked at it. By the way, I don't think it's going to hurt sales. They're the most conservative buyers there are.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A36398-2004Oct15.html|title=Nice Surprises in a Ho-Hum Package: 2005 Ford Five Hundred sedan|publisher=Washington Post, Warren Brown, October 17, 2004}}{{cite web|url=https://articles.latimes.com/2004/dec/08/autos/hy-neil8|title=A senior moment: Mercury's throwback Montego makes everything new feel old again.|publisher=LA Times, Dan Neil, December 08, 2004}} While the Five Hundred would attract attention for its high interior volume, design functionality, value, and large number of safety features, along with its styling, many reviewers criticized the performance of the 3.0L V6 engine and CVT transmission (in comparison to other vehicles).[https://web.archive.org/web/20110720073658/http://autos.nytimes.com/2006/Ford/Fusion/245/10005/278058/researchReviews.aspx "Car Review: The New York Times"]{{cite web|url=http://research.cars.com/go/crp/research.jsp?aff=pe&revid=50622&makeid=14&modelid=7655&year=2007&revlogtype=20§ion=reviews|title=Ford Five Hundred Expert Review|author=Mays, Kelsey|date=2006-11-27|work=Cars.com|accessdate=2007-02-17}}{{cite news|url=http://lfpress.ca/cgi-bin/publish.cgi?p=140394&x=articles&s=wheels|title=New siblings put Ford back in car game|author=Dear, Clare|date=2006-05-26|work=London Free Press|accessdate=2007-02-17|archive-url=https://archive.today/20060810110311/http://lfpress.ca/cgi-bin/publish.cgi?p=140394&x=articles&s=wheels|archive-date=2006-08-10|url-status=dead}} {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/automobiles/autoreviews/30AUTO.html|title=Much Ado About Another Do-Over|publisher=The New York Times, Christopher Jenson, August 28, 2009}} Ford designer J Mays said "I don't think the Five Hundred or Freestyle was one of my brighter moments in Ford, but designing a car is not a solo effort and a lot of people have input on the kind of product they want. I've been at the company 13 years and I've been through five CEOs. Some of those CEOs have had more conservative tastes than others."{{cite web|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20120924/OEM03/309249999/a-new-heyday-for-j-mays|title=A new heyday for J Mays|publisher=Automotive News, Dejan Jovanovic, September 16, 2014}} Mays later conceded of the Five Hundred's styling: “It’s just lacking in the emotional appeal that we should have put into it. We were being good team players, and we did our best to wrap what was a best-in-class package with sheetmetal, and we ended up with a car, I think, that compromised itself in terms of style. But we will never make that mistake again. In fact, we haven’t made a mistake like that since we did it. I think of all the cars I’ve designed in my career, I regret not pushing harder on that car.”{{cite web|url=http://www.autofieldguide.com/articles/j-mays-and-the-importance-of-the-story|title=J Mays and The Importance Of The Story|publisher=Automotive Design & Production, Gary S. Vasilash , Editor-in-Chief, 1/9/2007}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.myford500.com MyFord500.com]- Features news releases, links, photo galleries, and specifications. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130524183814/http://www.theusacar.com/cars/ford_five_hundred.htm 2006 Ford Five Hundred] {{Ford North America vehicles}} {{Ford United States & Canada timeline 1980 to present}} {{Ford vehicles}} {{Ford Taurus}} [[Category:Ford vehicles|Five Hundred]] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Ford D3 platform]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:Full-size vehicles]] [[Category:2000s cars]] [[Category:Ford Taurus|Five Hundred]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2005]] [[Category:Vehicles with CVT transmission]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

[[Mazda 6]] (Japan) }} The '''Ford Telstar''' is an [[automobile]] that was sold by [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] in Asia, [[Australasia]] and Africa, comparable in size to the European [[Ford Sierra]] and the North American [[Ford Tempo]]. It was progressively replaced by the [[Ford Mondeo]]. It was named after the [[Telstar]] satellite. Like the smaller [[Ford Laser]], the Telstar was based on a model produced by [[Mazda]] in Japan. It shared its [[automobile platform|platform]] with the [[Mazda Capella]]/626, the differences being confined to some styling, engine sizes, and specification. The first model was launched in Japan in 1982. The Australian launch occurred in 1983, replacing the [[Ford Cortina]]. Unlike the Cortina, the Telstar was usually only available as a [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] or five-door [[hatchback]] (known as the TX5). However, after 1988, a Telstar version of the 626 wagon was sold in [[Japan]] and [[New Zealand]]. In [[Taiwan]], it was assembled using [[knock-down kit|complete knock-down kits]] from 1983 via the local joint venture [[Ford Lio Ho]] in [[left-hand drive]].{{cite web |url=http://media.ford.com/plant_display.cfm?plant_id=129 |title=Plant Information |publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090918121234/http://media.ford.com/plant_display.cfm?plant_id=129 | archive-date = 18 September 2009}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=l5YSAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Ford+Telstar%22 |title=Japanese Motor Business |publisher=[[Economist Intelligence Unit]] |year=1994 |page=56 |quote=Ford's Taiwanese affiliate, Ford Lio Ho, has been involved in the alliance. Ford Lio Ho makes the Ford Festiva (based on the previous generation Mazda 121), the Ford Laser and the Ford Telstar, as well as commercial vehicles based on the Mazda Bongo.}} It remained in production in [[Malaysia]] until early 2001. 3-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]] }} Ford introduced the AR series Telstar sedan and hatchback to the Japanese market in October 1982—a rebadged and lightly restyled version of the then new [[front-wheel drive]], [[Mazda 626#GC|Mazda 626 (GC)]]—both manufactured at Mazda's [[Hōfu]] production line.{{cite news |last=Gover |first=Paul |date=2 November 1982 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/130826387 |title=Dual replacement |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=12 |access-date=12 August 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&ID=AB38CE858E1B0FCDCA257125001A149F |title=Ford Telstar (AR Telstar) |work=GoAuto |access-date=31 July 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&ID=5BAD55E3A8C2FC1CCA257125001A13F6 |title=Mazda 626 (GC) |work=GoAuto |access-date=12 August 2016}} The updated styling relative to the Mazda was performed by [[Ford Australia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wheelsmag.com.au/car-of-the-year/1501/car-of-the-year-highs-lows/ |title=Car of the Year: Highs & Lows |work=[[Wheels (magazine)|Wheels]] |date=20 January 2015 |access-date=22 July 2016}} This restyling effort made up part of the {{AUD|150 million}} Ford Australia spent on the Telstar, including setting up local production facilities.{{cite news |last=de Fraga |first=Christopher |date=14 June 1983 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gi5VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=npQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5279%2C6011618 |title=Telstar should keep Ford on top |work=[[The Age]] |page=15}} A [[drag coefficient]] of {{cd|0.36}} was achieved for the AR hatchback.{{cite news |last=de Fraga |first=Christopher |date=13 September 1983 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lxhVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XZQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4718,5996558 |title=Telstar has looks but needs better suspension |work=[[The Age]] |page=17}} The Telstar filled the gap in Ford Australia's product line-up left by the [[Ford Cortina#TF|TF Cortina]] in 1981. The [[Ford Laser#GA|Ford Meteor]] sedan had been positioned as a stop-gap replacement, despite occupying the [[car classification|segment below]].{{cite web |last=Stopford |first=William |date=12 May 2015 |url=http://www.curbsideclassic.com/curbside-classics-australian-brands/curbside-classic-1981-85-ford-kakb-laser-a-beam-of-light/ |title=1981–85 Ford KA/KB Laser – A Beam of Light |publisher=Curbside Classics |access-date=26 July 2016}}[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VP5jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BOcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6088%2C9177467 The right blend at the right time], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 25 May 1982 The AR Telstar was introduced to Australia in May 1983,{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&make=Ford&model=Telstar |title=Ford Telstar – Used Car Research |work=GoAuto |access-date=22 July 2016}} with GL, S and Ghia sedans, plus the TX5 and TX5 Ghia hatchbacks.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/186347533 |title=New Ford Telstar released at V.H. |newspaper=Victor Harbour Times |date=15 June 1983 |page=21 |access-date=31 July 2016}} For the local market, assembly occurred at Ford's [[Campbellfield, Victoria]] plant using [[complete knock-down]] (CKD) kits.{{cite web |url=http://www.uniquecarsandparts.com.au/car_info_ford_telstar_at.php |title=Ford Telstar AT/AV |publisher=Unique Cars and Parts |access-date=22 July 2016}} To free up plant capacity for the [[Ford Falcon (XF)]], production of the Telstar TX5 switched to Japan, with dealerships receiving the first shipments in February 1985.{{cite news |last=Gover |first=Paul |date=9 January 1985 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477231 |title=Ford imports complete cars |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=3 |access-date=26 July 2016}} [[File:Ford Telstar GL 2.0L (14997507012).jpg|thumb|left|1983–1985 Ford Telstar (AR) GL sedan]] [[File:1983-1985 Ford Telstar (AR) Ghia sedan 02.jpg|thumb|left|1983–1985 Ford Telstar (AR) Ghia sedan]] [[File:1983 Ford Telstar TX5 (AR) Ghia hatchback (2015-07-14) 02.jpg|thumb|left|1983–1985 Ford Telstar TX5 (AR) Ghia hatchback]] At launch, features unique to the AR series TX5 Ghia included an electric drivers' seat with adjustable side bolsters and electronic [[dashboard]] with LED [[tachometer]] and digital [[speedometer]].{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Pedr |date=12 July 1983 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/116417502 |title=Telstar comes in two body shapes |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=12 |access-date=31 July 2016}} [[Fluorescent lamp|Fluorescent]] vertical bars record the fuel level and engine temperature. Air conditioning was optional on all models, as was [[power steering]] on all except GL, S, and TX5 manuals. The S model added a height adjustable driver's seat and featured different upholstery over the GL. The AR series offered four- and five-speed manuals and three-speed automatic transmissions. The four-speed was standard on Telstar GL, with the five-speed standard on the remaining models, and the automatic optional on all models. There was only one engine on offer—a {{convert|70|kW|hp|abbr=on}} and {{convert|158|Nm|lbft|abbr=on}}, 2.0-litre with [[carburettor]].{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Graham |date=22 January 2009 |url=http://www.carsguide.com.au/car-reviews/used-car-review-ford-telstarmazda-626-1983-1987-13213 |title=Used car review Ford Telstar/Mazda 626 1983–1987 |work=[[Herald Sun]] |access-date=31 July 2016}} After initially importing engines, Ford commenced manufacture at its [[Norlane, Victoria|Norlane, Geelong]] facility in late 1983, taking the place of the [[Ford 335 engine#Australia|former V8 powerplant]] at the facility. Local changes for the Australian model included front seat modifications which improved headroom, and suspension tuning. The suspension was fully [[independent suspension|independent]], with a coil/strut system fitted, incorporating anti-dive and negative offset geometry to aid stability in slippery conditions and under heavy braking. [[Anti-roll bar]]s were fitted front and rear. The TX5 suspension also featured electronic variable [[shock absorber]]s—adjustable via a dashboard buttons for normal, automatic or sport. Along with the 626, the Telstar was ''[[Wheels (magazine)|Wheels]]'' magazine's [[Wheels Car of the Year|Car of the Year]] for 1983. [[File:1985-1987 Ford Telstar (AS) GL sedan (15077321442).jpg|thumb|right|1985–1987 Ford Telstar (AS) GL sedan]] [[File:1986 Ford Telstar TX5 (AS) Turbo hatchback (2009-08-22).jpg|thumb|right|1986–1987 Ford Telstar TX5 (AS) Turbo hatchback]] A facelifted model (the AS) arrived to Australia in September 1985. This comprised minor restyling to the front and rear, a comprehensively updated interior, improved suspension, revised trim and more features.{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&ID=E7297D2438CFA0B3CA257125001A13F1 |title=Ford Telstar (AS Telstar) |work=GoAuto |access-date=31 July 2016}} Front [[turn signals]] were relocated from the headlamps to the bumper, with side repeaters added to the wrap-around sections of the front bumper.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/185636225 |title=1985 Telstar Range |newspaper=Victor Harbour Times |date=18 October 1985 |page=11 |access-date=31 July 2016}} Taillamps for the sedan were restyled, and all models received new [[hubcap]]s or [[alloy wheel|alloys]]. GL was now fitted with a left-hand side [[wing mirror]], with Ghia models gaining electric mirror operation. The AS update also benefited from [[window film|tinted]] side and rear glass for the GL sedan. Analogue instrumentation was now standard across the range, dispensing with the digital setup used previously by the TX5 Ghia. The new [[center console (automobile)|centre console]] housed audio equipment, a storage tray, gear lever and, on Ghia models, [[power window]] switches. Telstar GL and the base TX5 offered a more basic [[hand brake]] console integrating an ashtray for rear passengers. Ghia models featured an armrest console with acrylic "smoked glass" lid to provide extra storage. Compared to the AR series, console storage space for Ghia models was increased, as was [[glove compartment]] capacity across all trims. The seats were also revised—the work of Ford Australia—and a modification that only applied to the Ford-badged cars.{{cite news |last=Gover |first=Paul |date=1 October 1985 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/132367967 |title=Telstar no longer a pacesetter but still gives good value |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=11 |access-date=12 August 2016}} Other interior changes included those made to the stalk-mounted switchgear, and a new digital clock in the centre of the dashboard benefitting from a glare-prevention hood. The clock was previously located awkwardly ahead of the gear lever. Suspension changes for the AS series included uprated rear springs and reduction in rear anti-roll bar diameter. Improvements were also made to the TX5 Ghia's adjustable suspension. In terms of braking, Ghias were now fitted with four-wheel [[disc brake]]s; Telstar GL and TX5 retained front discs and rear [[drum brake|drums]]. Ventilated front disc brakes and semi-metallic pads were now fitted across the range to provide, in conjunction with the brake cooling ducts in the front valance, increased brake cooling capacity and reduced [[brake fade]] and squeal. In 1985, Ford sold 20,982 Telstars in Australia—the eighth best selling nameplate.{{cite news |last=Gover |first=Paul |date=18 February 1986 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/118206001 |title=Ford tops new-car sales again |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=15 |access-date=12 August 2016}} In March 1986, the TX5 Turbo flagship launched in Australia, with an {{convert|87|kW|hp|abbr=on}} and {{convert|200|Nm|lbft|abbr=on}} engine tied to a five-speed manual.{{cite news |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/185641087 |title=Turbopowered TX5 is unveiled by Ford |newspaper=Victor Harbour Times |date=21 March 1986 |page=15 |access-date=12 August 2016}} Standard equipment over the Ghia trim included two-tone paint, alloy wheels, rear [[spoiler (car)|spoiler]], three-spoke [[steering wheel]], air conditioning, power steering, and [[Pioneer Corporation|Pioneer]] sound system.{{cite news |last=Gover |first=Paul |date=18 March 1986 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/118107746 |title=Telstar upstages builders' badge |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=13 |access-date=12 August 2016}} Also in 1986, all Telstars were updated to run on unleaded petrol. In [[New Zealand]], the Telstar, like the Laser, was assembled locally from 1983 (replacing the highly successful Cortina range) at Ford's original Seaview plant near Lower Hutt and later at the Ford/Mazda joint venture plant in [[Wiri]], [[Auckland]], called Vehicle Assemblers of New Zealand (VANZ).[https://www.google.co.uk/search?num=30&hl=en&tbm=bks&ei=jcpVW8LzLsGvkwWTy7bgCQ&q=%22Within+VANZ%2C+these+are+generally+referred+to+as+the+Laser%2C+Telstar+and+Falcon%22&oq=%22Within+VANZ%2C+these+are+generally+referred+to+as+the+Laser%2C+Telstar+and+Falcon%22&gs_l=psy-ab.3...134034.197418.0.198797.4.4.0.0.0.0.128.394.2j2.4.0....0...1c.1j2.64.psy-ab..0.0.0....0.uwSGvW36_5c specification Mazda 626 and [[Mazda 323]] were initially assembled separately by Motor Holdings in [[Otahuhu]] but later joined the Telstar and Laser at VANZ.{{cite book The switch from local assembly was made possible by the accumulation of import credits obtained from the export of the Capri to the United States. The base GL sedan and hatchback carried over the AS's 2.0-litre inline-four engine producing {{convert|68|kW|abbr=on}}, while Ghia models featured a 2.2-litre 12-valve inline-four with {{convert|84|kW|abbr=on}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&ID=64DBBD1FA766B828CA257125001A133A |title=Ford Telstar (AT Telstar) |work=GoAuto |access-date=22 July 2016}} The flagship TX5 Turbo used a variation of the 2.2-litre engine, rated at {{convert|108|kW|abbr=on}} on premium fuel and gaining [[anti-lock braking system|anti-lock brakes]]. 1992, the Telstar (AV series) was only available as the Japanese-built, high-performance TX5 hatchback in Australia. However, the Corsair proved less popular than the Telstar had been, losing sales dramatically during 1991.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CcQTAQAAMAAJ&dq=ford+corsair+australia&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=corsair++ ''International Motor Business''], Volumes 149-152, Economist Intelligence Unit, 1992, page 68-80 In New Zealand, by contrast, the range remained unchanged, although it was later complemented by the [[Ford Sierra|Sierra]], this time imported from Belgium in small volumes as premium models, rather than assembled locally. It was offered as a 1.8-litre five-speed manual Ghia sedan or 2.0-litre automatic TX5 hatchback.{{cite news |last=Sulaiman |first=Raja |date=13 March 1988 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19880313&id=wFlPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EJADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5759,3285405 |title=Telstar with more class |work=[[New Straits Times]] |page=21}} In early 1990, a facelifted model was shown, with a new, smaller grille, modified taillights and a new 12-valve engine replacing the previous 2.0-litre. The 1.8-litre continued with {{convert|90|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} while the new 2.0-litre engine offered {{convert|110|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. There were three models on offer; the 1.8 sedan, 2.0 Ghia sedan, and 2.0 Ghia TX5.{{cite news |author=Leeps |date=11 February 1990 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19900211&id=6aFUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RpADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5422,2465909&hl=en |title=A revamped Ford Telstar |work=[[New Straits Times]] |page=21}} In Indonesia, this generation was marketed as the "Ford Telstar Thunder." {{clear}} == Third generation (AX, AY; 1991–1997) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Third generation (AX, AY) | image = 1993 Ford Telstar (AX) GLX sedan (2015-07-16) 01.jpg | caption = Ford Telstar (AX) GLX sedan | production = 1991–1996 (Japan)

4-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]] }} Following the introduction of the [[Mazda G platform#GE|GE platform]] Mazda 626, Ford introduced its Telstar version to Japan in October 1991 at Japanese Ford dealerships called ''[[Mazda#marques|Autorama]]''. In Japan the GE-based Telstar was available in a range of sedan models with all four cylinder and V6 engine options and a TX5 hatchback range featuring only the V6 engines. The [[Mazda G platform#GV|GV platform]] Telstar wagon also continued alongside the sedan and hatchback. All variants were available in a large variety of trim levels, with many offering high levels of equipment in comparison to other markets. All were replaced by the [[Mazda G platform#GF|GF platform]] based Telstar in 1997. [[File:1993 Ford Telstar (AX) GLX sedan (2015-07-16) 02.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Telstar (AX) GLX sedan]] The AX series came to Australia in December 1992. Then followed the decision by [[Nissan]] to end [[Nissan Pintara]] manufacturing in Australia during 1992, whereby Ford's rebadged version, the Corsair was also discontinued. This left the Telstar as the Ford's sole offering in the mid-size segment of the market. This model was voted as ''[[Wheels magazine|Wheels]]'' magazine's [[Car of the Year]] for 1992. Trim levels were LX, GLX, Ghia and GT. The GT model was also available as a [[special edition]] between 1991 and 1992. Four-wheel steering was offered in the top-of-the-range Telstar. A facelifted AY model appeared in August 1994. The Telstar was replaced in Australia by the Mondeo in 1995. New Zealand, like Australia received the AX Telstar in 1992, followed by the AY in late 1994. NZ versions were offered in GLi, GLEi, Ghia sedan and TX5i, TX5 XRi hatchback forms, using 1.8 & 2.0-litre four cylinder and 2.5-litre V6 engines. The wagon version of the previous generation Telstar continued in local production along with the previous generation sedan offered as an entry-level model called the Telstar Orion. Both models retained the earlier 2.0-litre SOHC four cylinder engine. All Telstar models were assembled alongside a similar lineup of Mazda 626 models (except for the Ford-only Orion) at the Ford-Mazda joint venture Vehicle Assemblers of New Zealand (VANZ) plant in Wiri, South Auckland. When the first [[Ford Mondeo|Mondeos]] were offered abroad, Ford New Zealand offered the four cylinder AY sedan in two trim levels: Telstar Contour and Telstar Mystique (named after the respective US Ford and [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]] versions of the Mondeo) as a replacement for the GLi and GLEi respectively. Also in the AY lineup was a Telstar Eurosport V6 sedan (replacing the V6 GLEi) and upgraded TX5i and TX5 XRi hatchback models. A limited edition V6 sedan with tuned suspension and unique trim, known as the Telstar Radisich after the New Zealand racing driver [[Paul Radisich]] was also sold locally. This was released in two runs of 100 cars each, firstly in 1994 (based on the AX GLEi) and again in 1996 (based closely on the AY Eurosport).{{cite web|title=Ford Telstar Radisich|url=https://feather.wordpress.com/2013/09/13/ford-telstar-radisich/|date=13 September 2013}} Notable features of the model are 16" ROH Astron alloy wheels, the 'aero' body kit (similar to the TX5 XRi) and Radisich insignia decals. {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = 1995 Ford Telstar TX5 (AY) Ghia V6 hatchback (2015-07-14) 01.jpg | image2 = 1995 Ford Telstar TX5 (AY) Ghia V6 hatchback (2015-07-14) 02.jpg | caption2 = Ford Telstar (AY) Ghia V6 hatchback }} Local assembly of the Telstar ceased along with all other Ford and Mazda models in 1997 when the VANZ Auckland plant closed. It was replaced in all forms by the Belgian-built [[Ford Mondeo|Mondeo]] range. The Telstar was always a popular seller for Ford New Zealand. In South Africa, the Telstar replaced the Sierra in 1993, being assembled by [[Samcor]] alongside the Mazda 626.{{cite book |editor1-last=Reuvid |editor1-first=Jonathan | date =1995 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zPwxAQAAIAAJ&dq=Telstar |title=Doing Business in South Africa |publisher=[[Kogan Page]] |page=270 |isbn=9780749413477}} As in New Zealand, a Telstar Contour and Telstar Mystique were offered. In 1998, the Telstar was replaced by the Mondeo, which was later fully imported. In Malaysia, the third generation Telstar arrived in August 1992. It was initially available as a four-cylinder 2.0-litre sedan or as a better-equipped hatchback (designated "TX-5") which came with a V6 engine, also of 2.0-litre displacement. The four-cylinder model was paired with a five-speed manual transmission, while the V6 received a four-speed automatic.{{cite news |last=Haron |first=Sharif |date=29 August 1992 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1303&dat=19920827&id=2gUQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=d5ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=2720,5637030 |title=New Telstar for the executive |work=[[Business Times (Kuala Lumpur)|Business Times]] |page=6}} Later, the {{convert|150|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} V6 was also installed in the sedan and became available coupled to a manual transmission in the TX-5. In 1997, the Telstar in Malaysia received a new grille insert and the automatic tranmission eventually found its way into the 4-cylinder 16-valve 2.0-litre engine variant.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-VRIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lRQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3274%2C2581723 |title=The Ford Telstar comes with so many features, the remote control even changes TV channels |publisher=Ford Malaysia |date=14 February 2000}} Production ended in early 2001.{{cite news |url=http://autoworld.com.my/news/2001/05/18/Ford-s-Success-Story-in-Malaysia/ |title=Ford’s Success Story in Malaysia |location=Malaysia |publisher=Autoworld |date=18 May 2001 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820054000/http://autoworld.com.my/news/2001/05/18/Ford-s-Success-Story-in-Malaysia/ |archive-date=20 August 2016}} However, unsold stock lasted until 2003.{{cite web |url=https://www.axa.com.my/assets/smartdrive/pdf/flas-agreed-market-value-25.12.pdf |title=Master Listing |publisher=[[AXA]] Malaysia |date=26 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820054415/https://www.axa.com.my/assets/smartdrive/pdf/flas-agreed-market-value-25.12.pdf |archive-date=20 August 2016}} In Indonesia, this generation was offered with the 2-liter inline-four or the 2.5-liter V6, and was sold as the Telstar Brilliant (four-door sedan) and the Telstar Challenge (five-door liftback). {{clear}} == Fourth generation (1994–1997) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Fourth Generation | image = 1994 Ford TelstarII 01.jpg | aka = [[Mazda Capella]] | production = 1994–1997 | assembly = Japan: [[Hofu (Mazda factory)|Hofu]] | body_style = 4-door [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] | layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|Transverse front-engine, front-wheel drive]]

[[Mercury Tracer]] }} The '''Ford Laser''' is a [[compact car]], originally a [[subcompact car]] in the first three generations, which was sold by [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] in Asia, Oceania, and parts of South America, and Africa. It has generally been available as a sedan or hatchback, although convertible, wagon and pick-up versions have also been available in different markets. The sedan, and briefly station wagon, versions were badged '''Ford Meteor''' in Australia between 1981 and 1987. The Ford Meteor name was also used in South Africa. The Ford Laser was a restyled version of the [[Mazda Familia|Familia/323]] models produced by [[Mazda]] in Japan from 1980 onwards. Ford had acquired a 25% stake in Mazda in 1979. Platform and assembly-line sharing with the locally produced [[Mazda Familia]] in Japan allowed the Laser in that market to be offered with a plethora of engine, paint and trim configurations not available anywhere else in the world. This was most notably evident during the 1980s with multiple turbocharged variants, unique bodyshells such as the cabriolet, and full-time 4WD models all available years before their debuts in other markets (and in some cases, never making it offshore at all). Along with the Japanese produced [[Ford Telstar]] and [[Ford Festiva]], the Laser was sold at special ''Autorama'' dealerships.{{citation |url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=-Nm2AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover |title=Phase I: Japan's distribution system and options for improving U.S. access |publisher=[[United States International Trade Commission]] |date=June 1990 |volume=332 |issue=283 |page=59}} In Australia and New Zealand, where Ford was seen as a local brand, the locally assembled Laser outsold its Mazda twin, the 323, especially in Australia, where the 323 was imported.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5OoxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mJIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3080%2C4077082 Australia Welcomes The 'new' Migrants], ''[[The Age]]'', June 16, 1986, page 43 According to research carried out by [[Ford Australia]] in 1984, a third of Laser buyers were unaware that the Ford model was based on the Mazda 323.{{cite news |last=de Fraga |first=Christopher |date=1 June 1984 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jhoRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5JQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2509,159472 |title=Family tree bears fruit |newspaper=[[The Age]] |page=18 |access-date=8 September 2016}} However, in neighbouring Asian markets, such as Singapore, [[Malaysia]] and Hong Kong, as well as Japan itself, the reverse was the case, although pooling resources with Mazda allowed Ford to maintain a foothold in the region. This was also the case in South America, South Africa, and the [[Caribbean]], where the Laser was also sold, in many cases being locally assembled. __TOC__ {{clear}} == First generation (KA/KB; 1981–1985) == {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation (KA/KB) | image = 1982 Ford Laser (KA) Ghia 5-door hatchback (22643862523).jpg | interiorimage= 1983-1985 Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door hatchback 03.jpg | caption = Ford Laser (KA) Ghia 5-door | interiorcaption = Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door | aka = Ford Meteor (sedan) | production = 1981–1985 (Laser)

3-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]] }} === {{anchor|KA|KB}} Laser (KA/KB) === The KA Laser (Australian model code), built under license from Mazda, was introduced in March 1981, replacing the rear-wheel-drive Escort in Australia. The range was available as a hatchback, in both three- and five-door varieties, as well as a four-door sedan badged Ford Meteor. Originally sold only with the 1.3-litre engine, the smaller 1.1-litre engine was never available in Australia. Later, 1.5-litre versions were added, eventually even a turbocharged version. In January 1983, the Laser underwent a facelift to become the KB.{{cite book |editor1-last=Mastrostefano |editor1-first=Raffaele |year=1985 |title=Quattroruote: Tutte le Auto del Mondo 1985 |language=Italian |location=[[Milan]] |publisher=Editoriale Domus S.p.A |page=371 |isbn=88-7212-012-8 |ref=TAM85}} Light changes were made to the rear, while the front was redesigned in a more modern style, aligning it with Ford's corporate look of the era. In Japan this is referred to as the "BE" Laser, which was identical to the Australian KB series. The BE model code relates to the BD model code used for the corresponding Familia/323. The first Lasers went on sale in Japan in late 1982. Fuel-injection and a [[Mazda E engine#E5T|115 PS turbocharged model]] were added in July 1983; these variants were never offered for sale outside Japan. Aside from being built in Australia and Japan, Lasers were also assembled in New Zealand at Ford's Wiri plant in Auckland, replacing the Mk2 Escort. In New Zealand, the Laser was sold as both a hatchback and sedan, the Meteor name not being used in that market, and was later joined by the Mazda 323 at the renamed Vehicle Assemblers of New Zealand (VANZ) plant in [[Wiri]], [[Auckland]] in a joint venture between [[Ford New Zealand]] and Mazda. 323s initially had been assembled at the Motor Industries International plant in Otahuhu, subsequently taken over by Mazda New Zealand. New Zealand-built Ford Laser hatchbacks were available with the 1.1-litre (base and Ritz), 1.3-litre (GL), and 1.5-litre (Sport) engines, while the Laser sedan (base, L, Ghia) was available with the 1.1-, 1.3 and 1.5-litre engines respectively, with the Ghia having an automatic transmission option.''[[#TAM85|Tutte le Auto del Mondo 1985]]'', p. 424 {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 200 | image1 = Ford Laser KA Ghia (16204159755).jpg | caption1 = Ford Laser (KA) Ghia 5-door | image2 = 1984 Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door hatchback (2015-05-29) 01.jpg | caption2 = Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door | image3 = 1983-1985 Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door hatchback 05.jpg | caption3 = Ford Laser (KB) GL 5-door | image4 = 1983-1985 Ford Laser (KB) S 3-door hatcback (22586687328).jpg | caption4 = Ford Laser (KB) S 3-door | image5 = 1985 Ford KB Laser Turbo (6057997207).jpg | caption5 = Ford Laser (KB) Turbo }} The Laser was also sold in some countries in [[Latin America]], including [[Argentina]], where the local model was identical to the KA version sold in Australia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/ifhp97/5053482790/|title=1981 Ford Laser (Argentina)|date=October 4, 2010|via=Flickr}} In Mexico, however, the first-generation Laser had a front end similar to the North American [[Mazda Familia#BD|Mazda GLC]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/aussiefordadverts/11991427676/|title=1981 Ford KA Laser Brochure - Mexico|date=January 17, 2014|via=Flickr}} In addition, it was sold in [[right hand drive]] markets in the [[Caribbean]] such as [[Jamaica]] and [[Trinidad and Tobago]], where it was locally assembled.[http://www.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2013-09-07/charles-mcenearney-and-ford-94-year-partnership Charles McEnearney and Ford A 94-year partnership], ''[[Trinidad Guardian]]'', September 8, 2013 Assembly of the Laser also occurred in [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] (in [[right hand drive]]) and in [[left hand drive]] for markets like [[Taiwan]] and the [[Philippines]]. In Taiwan, it was assembled using [[knock-down kit|complete knock-down kits]] from 1981 via the local joint venture [[Ford Lio Ho]].{{cite web |url=http://media.ford.com/plant_display.cfm?plant_id=129 |title=Plant Information |publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090918121234/http://media.ford.com/plant_display.cfm?plant_id=129 |archive-date=2009-09-18}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=l5YSAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Ford+Telstar%22 |title=Japanese Motor Business |publisher=[[Economist Intelligence Unit]] |year=1994 |page=56 |quote=Ford's Taiwanese affiliate, Ford Lio Ho, has been involved in the alliance. Ford Lio Ho makes the Ford Festiva (based on the previous generation Mazda 121), the Ford Laser and the Ford Telstar, as well as commercial vehicles based on the Mazda Bongo.}} The Laser was also introduced in [[Zimbabwe]] in 1981, the first Ford model to be sold in the country for fourteen years, after the imposition of sanctions on the then [[Rhodesia]] after its [[Unilateral Declaration of Independence (Rhodesia)|Unilateral Declaration of Independence]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xYsqAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Ford+Laser%22+%22Zimbabwe%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Ford+Laser%22++ ''Automotive News''], Issues 4883-4895, 1981, page 116 It was assembled at the state-owned Willowvale Motor Industries plant, in [[Harare]], alongside the Mazda 323. * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E1|E1]]'', {{convert|41|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.1-litre, carburettor, 8-valve, [[SOHC]] (Base/Ritz, trim levels in New Zealand) * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E3|E3]]'', {{convert|49|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.3-litre carburettor, 8-valve, SOHC (L and GL in NZ) * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E5|E5]]'', {{convert|54|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.5-litre carburettor, 8-valve, SOHC (L & GL [Australia] and Ghia [NZ and Australia]) * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E5|E5]]'', {{convert|59|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.5-litre twin-carburettor, 8-valve, SOHC (Sport) * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E5T|E5T]]'', {{convert|78|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.5-litre carburettor, 8-valve, SOHC, [[turbocharger|turbocharged]] (limited edition Turbo trim level, 300 produced) * Mazda ''[[Mazda E engine#E5T|E5T]]'', {{convert|85|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.5-litre, electronic [[fuel injection]], 8-valve SOHC, turbocharged (Turbo trim level in Japan) === {{anchor|GA|GB}} Meteor (GA/GB) === Introduced in April 1982,{{cite news |last=de Fraga |first=Christopher |date=24 April 1982 |title=Mazdas being built by robots |newspaper=[[The Age]] |page=115 |quote=Ford has just shown its Meteor to the Press}}. Ford Meteor was the name given to the [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] version of the Laser.{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Pedr |date=31 August 1982 |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/126892442 |title=Ford puts in the boot: Japanese design a good decision |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |page=18 |access-date=26 July 2016}} Designated as the GA series,{{cite web |url=http://www.uniquecarsandparts.com.au/car_info_ford_laser.php |title=Ford Laser, Meteor and Telstar Reviews and Road Tests |publisher=Unique Cars and Parts |access-date=26 July 2016}} the Meteor featured conventional [[three-box styling]] with a 60/40 folding rear seat to increase luggage capacity that was already considered "very large for the class". Compared to the Laser, the front seats could be moved back a little further at the expense of rear seat passengers. To further improve practicality, the Meteor's spare wheel could be relocated from the floor to an upright position to increase boot depth from {{convert|410|to|585|mm|in}}. The additional length of {{convert|195|mm|in}} over the Laser hatchback was used by Ford Australia to justify the Meteor as replacement to the [[Ford Cortina#Mark V (1979–1985)|TF Cortina]]. In Australia, the Meteor was only available with the 1.5-litre engine and five-speed manual transmission or optional three-speed automatic. Consequently, the Meteor had a difficult undertaking replacing the Cortina, which offered [[engine displacement]]s from 2.0 litres for the inline-four, up to a 4.1-litre inline-six, plus a [[station wagon]] option.{{cite web |last=Stopford |first=William |date=12 May 2015 |url=http://www.curbsideclassic.com/curbside-classics-australian-brands/curbside-classic-1981-85-ford-kakb-laser-a-beam-of-light/ |title=1981–85 Ford KA/KB Laser – A Beam of Light |publisher=Curbside Classics |access-date=26 July 2016}} However, the Meteor's pitch as the Cortina replacement was merely a temporary measure prior to the introduction of the [[Ford Telstar|Telstar]] [[mid-size car|mid-sized]] sedan and hatchback in May 1983.{{cite web |last=de Fraga |first=Christopher |date=14 June 1983 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gi5VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=npQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5279%2C6011618 |title=Telstar should keep Ford on top |work=[[The Age]] |page=15 |quote=The Telstar is really Ford's Cortina replacement}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&make=Ford&model=Telstar |title=Ford Telstar – Used Car Research |work=GoAuto |access-date=22 July 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/carfamilytree?ReadForm&ID=AB38CE858E1B0FCDCA257125001A149F |title=Ford Telstar (AR Telstar) |work=GoAuto |access-date=22 July 2016}} In Australia, the Meteor directly competed against the [[Holden Camira#JB|Holden Camira]]. The Meteor's front styling and grille differed from the corresponding Laser. The Meteor styling was based on the Japanese market [[Mazda Familia#BD|Mazda Familia (BD)]] sedan.{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/details/Mazda_201607 |title=Mazda Familia (BD) 1300 and 1500 saloon (Japanese brochure) |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Mazda]] |year=1981 |access-date=26 July 2016}} Lighting changes included the replacement of the Laser's amber front [[turn signals]] with clear lenses, plus the fitment of larger, flush [[headlamp]]s over the Laser's smaller lights that were "sunken" into an enclosure. The Meteor grille had more of an "[[eggcrate]]" pattern than the plain black slats of the Laser. Suspension was [[Independent suspension|fully independent]] with [[coil spring]]s. Trim levels in Australia comprised the entry-level GL and upmarket Ghia, both available with an optional "S" pack that added full instrumentation and upgraded tyres. Steel wheels with bright metal trim rings differentiated the GL from the Ghia with its alloy wheels and deep side protection mouldings. The mid-term facelifted model of May 1983, coded GB, brought the range closer together, though Meteors continued as a separate and slightly more premium line. {{gallery | width = 202 | height = 120 |File:1982 Ford Meteor (GA) GL sedan (8731163710).jpg | Ford Meteor (GA) GL sedan |File:1982 Ford Meteor (GA) GL sedan (19986515862).jpg | Ford Meteor (GA) GL sedan |File:1984 Ford Meteor (GB) Ghia sedan (2015-07-06) 01.jpg | Ford Meteor (GB) Ghia sedan |File:1983 Ford Meteor (GB) GL sedan (18913598092).jpg | Ford Meteor (GB) GL sedan }} {{clear}} == Second generation (KC/KE; 1985–1989) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation (KC/KE) | aka = Ford Meteor | image = 1985-1987 Ford Laser (KC) Ghia 5-door hatchback 01.jpg | caption = Ford Laser (KC) Ghia 5-door | production = Japan: 1985–1989

4/5-speed [[manual transmission|manual]] }} === Japan === January 1985 saw the advent of the BF series Laser in Japan. This was the Laser's first major redesign. For the first time a diesel version was offered in Japan, as well as a factory two-door cabriolet, a DOHC 16-valve Sport version, and a potent [[Mazda B engine#B6T|140 PS DOHC turbo]] model with full-time 4WD drivetrain (identical to the contemporary Mazda Familia BFMR). This added up to an extremely convoluted Japanese product line, which was later streamlined in 1987 with a mid-life model refresh (KE series in other markets). This refresh dropped E-series engines in favour of all-new B-series equivalents, poorer-selling variants were discontinued, and minor changes were made to exterior styling and interior trim. [[File:1985-1987 Ford Laser (KC) TX3 3-door hatchback (20246992365).jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KC) TX3 3-door]] [[File:1986 Ford Laser (KC) GL 5-door hatchback (2015-07-14) 02.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KC) GL 5-door]] [[File:1987 Ford Meteor (GC) GL station wagon (2015-06-27) 01.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Meteor (GC) GL wagon]] ===Asia=== The Laser was also sold in Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Sri Lanka, and other markets. Trim and speicifications vary somewhat between the countries. In Indonesia, this Laser was available (in Ghia trim only) beginning in late 1985 with the 1296 cc engine with {{convert|68|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}}, a five-speed manual transmission, and five-door hatchback or four-door saloon bodywork.{{cite magazine | magazine = Mobil & Motor | language = Indonesian | title = Baru: Ford Laser Ghia | trans-title = New: Ford Laser Ghia | page = 28 | volume = XV | number = 10 | date = 1985-11-11 | publisher = PT Inscore Indonesia | ref = mm85 | editor-last = Susanto | editor-first = Tias | issn = 0047-7591 }} Later, a non-emissions scrubbed Laser TX-3 with the fuel injected B6 engine became available. This produced a claimed {{convert|104|PS|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 6000 rpm.{{cite magazine | magazine = Mobil & Motor | language = Indonesian | title = TX-3 kalahkan 240-RS |trans-title=TX-3 beats the 240 RS | page = 32 | volume = 16 | number = 17 | date = 1987-03-01 | publisher = PT Informedia Indonesia | last = Hidayat | first = Arief | issn = 0047-7591 }} ===Australia and New Zealand=== For Australia, the range was known as the KC Laser and GC Meteor, launched in October 1985. All bodystyles were carried over, with the addition of a station wagon (badged as "Meteor", like the sedan) from 1986. A new "TX3" variant, which was at the top of the "Laser" models in specification level and designated "KC2", replaced the "Sport" variant from the KB series. Unlike the Sport, the TX3 was only available as a three-door (the Taiwanese TX3 was available in a five-door version only). The "L" and "GL" models were no longer available as a three-door. A notable change was the introduction of engines capable of running on 91 RON unleaded petrol (this became mandatory in Australia from 1986). [[File:1985-1987 Ford Meteor (GC) GL sedan 01.jpg|thumb|Ford Meteor (GC) GL sedan]] [[File:1987 Ford Meteor (GC) GL station wagon (2015-06-27) 02.jpg|thumb|Ford Meteor (GC) GL wagon]] The ''E5'' 1.5-litre SOHC carburettored engine that was optional on GL, and standard on Ghia in the KB series was replaced with the new ''B6'' 1.6-litre I4 SOHC. For the first time, electronic fuel injection was available as an option on Ghia models, and was standard on TX3 models. Buyers who ordered automatic transmission with this engine received an electronically controlled four-speed unit, which was quite advanced for a small car in 1985. The ''B3'' I4 SOHC 1.3-litre engine was standard on the "L" (hatchback only, the wagon had a 1.6-litre engine). The 1.6-litre engine was standard on GL, Ghia and TX3, though some early GL models were equipped with a 1.5-litre SOHC carburettored. The KC/KE Laser wagon was also assembled in New Zealand, alongside its Mazda 323 equivalent, until Ford closed their VANZ assembly plant at [[Wiri]], [[Auckland]] in 1996. KC / GC model range (Australia): * Laser L * Laser GL * Laser Ghia * Laser TX3 * Meteor L (wagon only) * Meteor GL * Meteor Ghia === North America === A version of the KC Laser, the [[Mercury Tracer]], was marketed in the US and Canada, available as a hatchback and wagon only. The Tracer hatchback shared its bodyshell with its Laser counterpart, but the wagon was a distinct design based on the Laser hatchback, rather than the sedan, as was the case with the Meteor wagon. US versions of the Tracer were built in Mexico, whereas for the Canadian market, Ford opted to import the Mercury Tracer from [[Taiwan]] instead.{{cite book |last1=Feenstra |first1=Robert C |last2=Hamilton |first2=Gary G |year=2006 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4lEKRJSIVIEC |title=Emergent Economies, Divergent Paths: Economic Organization and International Trade in South Korea and Taiwan |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |page=311 |isbn=9781139447232}} In [[Bermuda]], however, the KE Laser was sold locally in right hand drive badged as a Ford.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2tZkAAAAMAAJ&q=%22ford+laser%22+%22bermuda%22&dq=%22ford+laser%22+%22bermuda%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7iq7Q94vRAhXKeFAKHfs8DS0Q6AEIIDAB ''The Bermudian''], Volume 58, 1988, page xcix === {{anchor|KE}} Laser (KE) === [[File:1987-1990 Ford Laser (KE) L 5-door hatchback (2011-01-13).jpg|thumb|Ford Laser (KE) L 5-door]] [[File:1989-1990 Ford Laser (KE) GL station wagon (2011-11-08).jpg|thumb|1989–1990 Ford Laser (KE) GL wagon]] In October 1987, Ford introduced a facelift of the KC series, the KE. There were a number of notable changes with the introduction of the KE. The "Meteor" name was dropped from the sedan and wagon body styles, meaning they were now badged as "Laser", like the hatchback variants. The TX3 was also now available with a turbocharged engine and all-wheel-drive (AWD) as options. The TX3 Turbo with AWD is now very rare and highly sought after. The AWD was fully imported from Japan, while all other models in the Laser range were manufactured locally in the Sydney suburb of Homebush. The KE is easy to distinguish from the earlier KC, by different grilles, headlights, tail lights, body-side mouldings, bonnet, front guards, and on some models, wheels. The dashboard and instrument cluster received new graphics, and the interior was available in slightly different colour shades to the KC. In mid-1989, in preparation for a new ADR (Australian Design Rule) to come into effect in 1990, all models were fitted with a high-mount rear stop lamp as standard. When the redesigned KF Laser was introduced in March 1990, the wagon continued in a sole GL specification, with minor upgrades until September 1994, when Australian production of the Laser ceased. [[File:1987-1990 Ford Laser (KE) GL 5-door hatchback 09.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KE) GL 5-door]] [[File:1989 Ford Laser (KE) GL sedan (2015-11-13).jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KE) GL sedan]] [[File:1993 Ford Laser (KE II) GL station wagon (2009-11-29).jpg|thumb|left|1991–1994 Ford Laser (KE II) GL wagon]] The "L" is quite rare, as it was primarily aimed at the budget or fleet buyer and available as a five-door hatchback and station wagon. It had silver-painted 13-inch steel wheels, with no centre caps, a large analogue clock in the instrument cluster, no passenger-side [[rear-view mirror]], vinyl interior trim, no body side mouldings, no rear windscreen wiper, and the folding rear seat was only one-piece. The stereo was also AM-only and had no cassette player. Air conditioning was not available. The only engine on offer was the 1.3-litre engine, with four-speed manual transmission (no automatic was available). The "L" wagon had the same level of trim, except the 1.3-litre engine was replaced with the 1.6-litre unit, but still with four-speed transmission (automatic was not available on either the hatchback or wagon). The "GL" was the most popular model. It featured the same silver-painted 13" steel wheels as the "L" but with satin chrome half-width centre caps (only covering the centre of the wheel), a digital clock on the top of the dashboard, cloth interior trim, grey body side mouldings, a rear windscreen wiper, grey tailgate and beaver panel garnishes and 50/50 split-fold rear seat. The stereo was an analogue-tuned AM/FM unit with a basic cassette player. Air conditioning was optional as a dealer-fit accessory. Power was provided by a 1.6-litre engine, with 4-speed manual transmission (5-speed manual or 3-speed automatic was optional). Sedan and wagon came standard with five-speed transmission. The Ghia was the luxury model. It had black 14-inch steel wheels with full-size plastic wheel covers, power steering, body-coloured rear-view mirrors and bumpers, velour interior trim, tachometer, centre console with Ghia emblem, lockable glovebox, driver's seat with lumbar support and height adjust, storage drawer underneath the front passenger seat, full-size interior door trims, vanity mirror in passenger sunvisor, ticket holder in driver's sunvisor, felt interior headlining and sunvisors, rear headrests, additional warning lights in the instrument cluster, central locking with illuminated driver's door lock barrel, remote exterior mirrors, front door map pockets, front seatback pockets, additional reading lamps, chrome insert strips in the body side mouldings and bumpers, red tailgate garnish and orange beaver panel garnish. Air conditioning and power windows were optional. The stereo was a digitally tuned AM/FM unit, which featured a cassette player with Dolby enhanced sound. The 1.6-litre engine was fitted as standard, with EFI optional (standard on wagon), with either 5-speed manual or 3-speed automatic transmission (EFI automatic was 4-speed). [[File:1989 Ford Laser (KE) GL Redline 5-door hatchback (2008-05-07).jpg|thumb|Ford Laser (KE) GL Redline 5-door]] [[File:1989 Ford Laser (KE) Ghia 5-door hatchback (2015-07-10) 02.jpg|thumb|Ford Laser (KE) Ghia 5-door]] [[File:1987-1990 Ford Laser (KE) TX3 3-door hatchback 01.jpg|thumb|Ford Laser (KE) TX3 3-door]] The TX3 was the Laser flagship. It came standard with 14-inch satin-chrome alloy wheels, sports cloth interior trim, red insert strips in the body side mouldings and bumpers, black tailgate and beaver panel garnishes, semi-bucket seats with adjustable seat height, back and lumbar support, auto fade interior lamps, and all other Ghia appointings. EFI and A/C was standard, and automatic transmission was not available. The TX3 also had a unique front fascia with quad headlights and the parker lamps incorporated into the indicator lenses (L/GL/Ghia had the parkers inside the main headlight unit) and two-tone paint. Halfway through KE production, Ford introduced two limited edition versions, called "Redline", and "Livewire". The Redline was based on the GL hatch, while the Livewire was based on the GL sedan and hatch. The Redline featured the TX3's alloy wheels, two-tone paint and red inserts in the body-side mouldings and bumpers, air conditioning, and a tachometer. The Livewire featured yellow inserts in the body side mouldings and bumpers, a body coloured grille, air conditioning, and a tachometer. Both models had 5-speed manual transmission (as opposed to the standard 4-speed) as standard, with 3-speed automatic transmission as an option. KE model range; * Laser L – Hatch or wagon * Laser GL – Hatch, sedan or wagon * Laser Ghia – Hatch, sedan or wagon * Laser TX3 * Laser TX3 Turbo * Laser TX3 Turbo 4WD Engine specifications: * Mazda E3, {{convert|49|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.3 L Carb 8V SOHC ('L' and 'GL' models) * Mazda E5T, {{convert|85|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.5 L EFI 8V SOHC Turbo ('Cabriolet' Japan models) * Mazda B6, {{convert|53|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.6 L Carb 8V SOHC ('GL' and 'GHIA' models) * Mazda B6, {{convert|62|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.6 L EFI 8V SOHC (option on 'GHIA' models and standard on 'TX3' models) * Mazda B6T, {{convert|100|kW|hp|abbr=on}} 1.6 L EFI 16V DOHC Turbo ('TX3 Turbo' and 'Turbo 4WD' models) ===South Africa=== The Laser was introduced in South Africa in 1986, as a hatchback, with the sedan version being sold as the Meteor. Replacing the [[Ford Escort (Europe)|Ford Escort]], it was produced alongside the Mazda 323 by [[Samcor]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YUVPAQAAIAAJ&dq=Samcor+Laser+Meteor&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Laser+Meteor ''Financial Mail''], Volume 104, Issues 5-9, page 221 In addition to the 1.3 L carb, 1.6 L carb and 1.6 L EFi engines, South African models of the Laser and Meteor also gained the Mazda ''[[Mazda F engine#FE-DOHC|FE-DOHC]]'' EFi 16-valve engine with {{convert|146|hp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|136|lbft|N·m|0|abbr=on}} from 1991 to 1993. The KC/KE Laser and Meteor remained in production in South Africa until 1995, when the Escort was reintroduced. However, Ford introduced an entry-level model called the Tonic and Tracer, a rebadged version of the locally manufactured BF series Mazda 323 hatchback, which was sold until 2003.[http://www.carmag.co.za/news_post/ford-mazda-zoom-apart/ Ford, Mazda Zoom Apart], ''CAR magazine'', September 1st 2002 From 1989, [[Ford CVH engine|Ford's CVH engines]] (1.4 and 1.6) were used, with fuel injection available for the 1600 Sport model. Again, a [[Mazda B engine#BPT|DOHC turbo model]] with full-time 4WD was offered as a companion car to the Mazda Familia GT-X, now producing {{convert|180|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} from an increased displacement of 1.8 litres. ===Australia=== In Australia, this model was released in March 1990 as the KF series and updated in October 1991 with the KH facelift. Local production of the Laser in Australia ceased in 4 September 1994 when Ford closed its plant at [[Homebush, New South Wales]], and imported the new KJ model from Japan;{{cite web |url=http://www.autoweb.com.au/cms/A_104206/title_Ford-Commemorates-80-Years-on-the-Line/newsarticle.html |title=Ford Commemorates 80 Years on the Line |work=AutoWeb |date=24 March 2005 |access-date=22 July 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324184817/http://www.autoweb.com.au/cms/A_104206/title_Ford-Commemorates-80-Years-on-the-Line/newsarticle.html |archivedate=24 March 2012 }} ===New Zealand=== In New Zealand, the KH Laser continued in production at Ford's assembly plant in [[Wiri]], [[Auckland]], until the end of 1996 when the factory closed. The extended production model in New Zealand was sold only in five-door hatchback form as either the '''Laser Encore''' or '''Laser Esprit''', as a cheaper alternative to the newer KJ Laser imported from Japan. The Encore was the cheaper of the two, available only with a five-speed manual transmission, while the Esprit was slightly higher specification and was available with both the five-speed and also a four-speed automatic. Both featured red pinstriping around the body and many received dealer-fit accessories such as alloy wheels to boost appeal. [[File:1990 Ford Laser (KF) Ghia sedan (22514037076).jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KF) Ghia sedan (Australia)]] [[File:1994 Ford Laser (KH) GL Horizon 5-door hatchback (2015-05-29).jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KH) GL Horizon 5-door (Australia)]] [[File:1990-1991 Ford Laser (KF) TX3 Turbo 3-door hatchback (14292571369).jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KF) TX3 4WD 3-door (Australia)]] [[File:1992 Ford Laser (KH) Ghia sedan (2016-01-04) 01.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KH) Ghia sedan (Australia)]] ===Other markets=== This generation of Laser was also sold in [[Cyprus]] and [[Malta]]. This generation was the basis of later [[Ford Escort (North America)|Escort]] models sold in North America from 1990 for the 1991 model year, which is not to be confused with the model of the same name sold in Europe. The Escort name was retained for the new model due to both strong brand equity on the Escort name as well as [[Chrysler]] already using the Laser name for the [[Plymouth Laser]]. The Escort wagon seen in North America during this generation was unique to that continent and was not part of the Laser ranges elsewhere. 3/4-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] }} ===Japan=== The fourth generation model was known as the BHA series in Japan. All sporting models were discontinued with the release of this model in the wake of poor sales and financial returns as Mazda scaled back operations and sought to rearrange market focus. Only the sedan and three-door hatchback were sold in Japan, the hatch being based on the Mazda Familia Neo. ===Australia=== The Japanese built KJ Laser in Australia released in October 1994 represented a major change in design; looking very different from the previous KH model. The three-door hatchback was known as the Laser Lynx and the five-door as the Laser Liata. The new KJ Laser was introduced in 1994 with variants, facelifts (KL of December 1996 and KM of December 1997) and engine driveline improvements continuing up until the last of the KM series were released in 1998. The KJ Laser was the first Laser manufactured wholly in Japan, following Ford Australia's decision to close their Homebush plant. However, the KJ was disappointing in sales numbers mainly because of the smaller [[Ford Festiva|Festiva]] and other cheaper South Korean models from Hyundai, Kia and Daewoo to which many conservative buyers flocked. [[File:1997 Ford Laser (KJ II (KL)) LXi sedan (2010-09-19) 02.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KL) LXi sedan (Australia)]] [[File:1994-1996 Ford Laser (KJ) Liata Ghia 5-door hatchback 01.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Laser (KJ) Liata Ghia 5-door (Australia)]] [[File:1995 Ford Laser (KJ) Lynx 3-door hatchback (2015-08-07).jpg|thumbnail|left|Ford Laser (KJ) Lynx 3-door (Australia)]] ===New Zealand=== With the introduction of the KJ Laser in 1994, Ford New Zealand found itself in a unique position, offering three different generations of the Laser as new vehicles at once at its dealerships—the new KJ Laser imported from Japan, the locally assembled previous-generation KH Laser as a five-door hatchback, and the older-shape KE Laser station wagon. This continued until 1996 when Ford NZ closed its [[Wiri]], [[Auckland]] factory. The second update KM Laser was not sold in New Zealand. The KL Laser, now replaced in Australia, continued to be sold alongside the European Ford Escort in New Zealand during 1997 but was discontinued locally at the end of the year, the Escort hatchback and sedan replacing it for just 16 months between January 1998 and May 1999 when the new KN Laser was introduced. ===Taiwan=== In [[Taiwan]], [[Ford Lio Ho Motor]] assembled the Laser sedan branded as the '''Ford Liata''';{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YmCPiqCNa0c |title=Ford Liata television commercial |location=Taiwan |publisher=[[Ford Lio Ho Motor]] |year=c. 1994 |access-date=8 September 2016}} the Lynx three-door version was rebranded as the '''Ford Aztec'''.{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mKQ39IlB6gg |title=Ford Aztec television commercial |location=Taiwan |publisher=[[Ford Lio Ho Motor]] |year=1995 |access-date=8 September 2016}} However, the Liata five-door version was not available in Taiwan, although the Mazda 323 was sold as a rebadged version of the Laser sedan only. ===Latin America=== In Latin America, this generation of Laser was assembled in [[Colombia]] and [[Venezuela]], alongside its Mazda 323 counterpart, known as the Mazda Allegro.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8pxaAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22ford+laser%22+colombia&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22ford+laser%22+ ''Business Venezuela''], Issues 203-212, Venezuelan-American Chamber of Commerce and Industry. 1998, page 92 Engine Specifications: * Mazda B6, 80 kW, 1.6L, 16V, DOHC ('LXi' models) * Mazda BP, 92 kW, 1.8L, 16V, DOHC ('GLXi' and some 'LXi' models) {{clear}} == {{anchor|KN|KQ}} Fifth generation (KN/KQ; 1998–2007) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Fifth generation (KN/KQ) | image = Ford Laser Lidea Wagon 001.JPG | caption = Ford Laser (KN) Lidea hatchback (Japan) | aka = Ford Life (hatchback only)
