"If our early numbers hold up, the Fusion Hybrid would be a rare instance of the EPA relapsing into the world of mileage make-believe." However, they noted that when driven very conservatively, the EPA numbers could be achieved. "In typical driving, you might as well throw the Fusion's EPA numbers out the window. But if you decide to really work at it, they're possible."{{cite web|url=http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/alternative/112_0901_2010_ford_fusion_hybrid_2009_toyota_camry_hybrid/fuel_economy.html|title=Comparison: 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid vs 2009 Toyota Camry Hybrid|publisher=[[Motor Trend]]|author=Kim Reynolds|date=January 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2010}} ''[[Car and Driver]]'' also tested a Fusion Hybrid and achieved no more than {{convert|34|mpgus|abbr=on}} over {{convert|300|mi}} of driving, which was greater than the Camry Hybrid ({{convert|31|mpgus}}) or Nissan Altima Hybrid ({{convert|32|mpgus}}) though not by the margin indicated by the EPA ratings.{{cite web|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/comparisons/09q1/2010_ford_fusion_hybrid_vs._camry_hybrid_altima_hybrid_and_malibu_hybrid-comparison_tests|title=2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid vs. Camry Hybrid, Altima Hybrid, and Malibu Hybrid – Comparison Tests|publisher=[[Car and Driver]]|date=February 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729182946/http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/comparisons/09q1/2010_ford_fusion_hybrid_vs._camry_hybrid_altima_hybrid_and_malibu_hybrid-comparison_tests|archivedate=July 29, 2010|df=mdy-all}} [[File:2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid WAS 2010 8962.JPG|thumb|The 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid promotional vehicle involved in the 1000 Mile Challenge]] According to Ford, the vehicle was built to have a fuel efficiency of 41 mpg in the city and 36 mpg on the highway by EPA standards.{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=29620|title=41 mpg! All-new FORD Fusion hybrid is now America's most fuel-efficient mid-size car|publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]]|date=December 23, 2008|accessdate=June 6, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604104051/http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=29620|archivedate=June 4, 2009|df=mdy-all}} On December 2008, Autoblog Green staff reported they had obtained in-city mileage of 43.1 mpg on the streets of Los Angeles.{{cite web |url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2008/12/13/abg-first-drive-2010-ford-fusion-hybrid-43-1-mpg-on-the-street/ |title=First Drive: 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid|publisher=AutoblogGreen |date=December 13, 2008 |accessdate=December 31, 2008 }} In addition, a [[Los Angeles Times]] reporter informed in December 2008 that he had obtained 52 mpg in mixed city-highway driving with little difficulty.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/dec/19/business/fi-neil19 |date=December 19, 2008 |title=2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid: 52 mpg and the darkness before dawn | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Dan | last=Neil | accessdate=May 2, 2010}} On a single-tank publicity stunt conducted on April 2009, a Fusion Hybrid managed {{convert|81.5|mpgus}} on a 1,445.7 mile trip.{{cite web|url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2009/04/28/ford-fusion-hybrid-hypermiles-goes-1-445-miles-on-a-single-tank/|date=April 28, 2009 |title=Ford Fusion hybrid hypermiles, goes 1,445 miles on a single tank }}{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/29/ford-hybrid-goes-1400-miles-on-single-tank-of-gas/?scp=1&sq=Ford%20Team%20drive%202010%20Fusion%20Hybrid%201,000%20Miles%20on%20a%20Single%20Tank%20of%20Gas&st=Search|title=Ford Hybrid Goes 1,400 Miles on Single Tank of Gas|work=New York Times | author=Jim Motavalli|date=April 29, 2009|accessdate=September 9, 2010}} [[Inside Line|Edmunds' InsideLine]] received a 2010 Fusion Hybrid as a long-term test car. Over {{convert|11000|mi}} of driving, their vehicle had only averaged {{convert|31.3|mpgus|abbr=on}}, with a best tank of {{convert|37.7|mpgus|abbr=on}} and a worst tank of {{convert|24.4|mpgus|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.insideline.com/roadtests/2010/12/2010-ford-fusion-hybrid-fuel-economy-update.html|title=2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid: Fuel Economy Update|publisher=Edmunds InsideLine| author=Scott Oldham|date=December 29, 2010|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} [[Ford Fusion Hybrid|Reduced Electric Vehicle Operation Of 2010 - 2012 Fusion Hybrid]] Many owners complained to Ford about greatly reduced gas mileage after 9 years of operation because of reduced electric vehicle operation and increased gasoline engine operation. Ford notified their dealers that they are investigating a fix: '''TSB #SSM 48238 "Oct 3 2019'''  8922 - 2010-2012 Fusion HEV, 2010-2011 Milan HEV, 2011-2012 MKZ HEV - Reduced ElectricVehicle Operation Some 2010-2012 Fusion hybrid electric vehicle (HEV), 2010-2011 Milan HEV and 2011-2012 MKZ HEV vehicles may experience reduced electric vehicle operation and increased gasoline engine operation. Do not attempt repairs at this time. Engineering is investigating, monitor OASIS for updates." ===Payback time=== According to [[Edmunds.com]], the price premium paid for the Fusion Hybrid takes 5 years to recover in fuel savings as compared to its non-hybrid sibling, and is one of the quickest payback periods among top selling hybrids as of February 2012. Edmunds compared the hybrid version priced at {{USD| 27,678}} with a comparably-equipped gasoline-powered Fusion priced at {{USD|24,493}} and found that the payback period is 6 years for gasoline at {{USD|3}} per gallon, 4 years at {{USD|4}} per gallon, and drops to 3 years with gasoline prices at {{USD|5}} per gallon. These estimates assume an average of {{convert|15,000|mi|abbr=on}} annual driving and vehicle prices correspond to Edmunds.com's true market value estimates.{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/industry-center/analysis/will-higher-gas-prices-boost-hybrid-ev-sales.html|title=Will Higher Gas Prices Boost Hybrid, EV Sales?|author=Michelle Krebs|publisher=[[Edmunds.com]]|date=February 28, 2012|accessdate=February 29, 2012}} For the same two vehicles, the U.S. EPA estimates the Fusion Hybrid annual fuel cost at {{USD|1,431}} while the gasoline-powered Fusion has an annual fuel cost of {{USD|2,320}}. EPA estimates are based on 45% highway and 55% city driving, over 15,000 annual miles, and gasoline price of {{USD|3.72}} per gallon, the national average as of February 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=31388&id=31391|title=Compare Side-by-Side - 2012 Ford Fusion Hybrid FWD and 2012 Ford Fusion FWD|author=[[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|date=February 2012|accessdate=February 29, 2012}} The [[Lincoln MKZ Hybrid]] has no price premium. ===SmartGauge for eco driving=== [[File:Ford Fusion Hybrid digital panels.jpg|thumb|Digital panels to keep track of [[eco driving]] style (top) and current drive propulsion (bottom).]] The Fusion Hybrid comes with a SmartGauge with EcoGuide which features two 4.3-inch high-resolution, full-color LCD screens on either side of the vehicle's [[analog signal|analog]] [[speedometer]]. The objective of these panel display is to coach drivers on how to optimize the performance of their hybrid by keeping track of their [[eco driving]] improvements.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2009/04/eco-driving-systems-now-your-car-can-gently-nag-you-into-being-more-fuel-wise.html|title=Eco-Driving Systems: Now Your Car Can Gently Nag You Into Being More Fuel-Wise|author=Robert E. Calem|publisher=[[Edmunds.com|Edmunds]]|accessdate=December 26, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913223435/http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2009/04/eco-driving-systems-now-your-car-can-gently-nag-you-into-being-more-fuel-wise.html|archivedate=September 13, 2010|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/images/10031/SmartGauge.pdf|title=2010 Ford Fusion SmartGauge with EcoGuide Coaches Drivers to Maximum Fuel Efficiency|publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]]|accessdate=December 26, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004130628/http://media.ford.com/images/10031/SmartGauge.pdf|archivedate=October 4, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://carspondent.com/2010-ford-fusion-hybrid/|title=2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid|publisher=Carspondent|date=May 26, 2009|accessdate=December 26, 2009}} These screens can be configured to show different levels of driver information, including fuel and battery power levels, and average and instant [[fuel economy in automobiles|fuel economy]]. When set in tutorial mode, the instrument panel in the right side “grows” leaves and vines on-screen to reward fuel-efficient driving. The more leaves and vines that appear, the more efficient the driving behavior is and the more fuel is being saved. Long-term fuel efficiency can also be displayed as a traditional chart. The left side display shows when the car is in pure-electric mode, and shows the state of battery charge. The [[Lincoln MKZ Hybrid|2011 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid]], launched in September 2010, offers an improvement of Ford's SmartGauge with EcoGuide introduced with the 2010 Fusion and Milan hybrids. In 2012, with the introduction of the second generation Fusion, Ford redesigned its SmartGauge with EcoGuide system giving it a newer look and new customizable MyView features. One of the new features, Brake Coach, gives instant feedback on the driver's braking habits and gives them advice to maximize the efficiency of the regenerative braking system. Other new features included, Inform, Enlighten, Engage, and Empower. ===Tax credit=== The Fusion Hybrid qualified for a maximum [[hybrid tax credit]] of US$3,400 if purchased by March 31, 2009. The credit dropped to US$1,700 if purchased by September 30, 2009, to US$850 if purchased from October 2009 and March 31, 2010, and phased out on April 1, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=29778|title=2010 Fusion and 2009 Escape Hybrids Provide Buyers Top Tax Credits|publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]]|date=January 28, 2009|accessdate=June 6, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818015022/http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=29778|archivedate=August 18, 2009|df=mdy-all}}
===Other markets=== The [[Brazil]]ian version of the Fusion Hybrid was unveiled at the 2010 [[São Paulo International Auto Show]]. Sales began in November 2010 at a price of {{currency|133,900|BRL}} ({{USD|78,500}}). The Fusion Hybrid was the first [[full hybrid|full hybrid car]] sold in Brazil.{{cite news|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/noticia/economia/fusao-verde-o-primeiro-hibrido-completo-do-brasil|language=Portuguese|title=Fusão verde: o primeiro híbrido completo do Brasil|work=[[Veja (magazine)|Veja]]|author=Luís Guilherme Barrucho|date=October 23, 2010|accessdate=October 24, 2010}} Imported from Mexico, the Fusion Hybrid engine performance and fuel system durability was tested with the Brazilian mandatory [[Common ethanol fuel mixtures#E20, E25|E20 to E25]] [[ethanol]] blends.{{cite web|url=http://www.protec.org.br/noticias.asp?cod=6959|language=Portuguese|title=Sonho do carro elétrico está mais perto do brasileiro|publisher=Protec|author=Valor Econômico|date=October 1, 2010|accessdate=October 24, 2010}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Second generation== {{Infobox electric vehicle |image=Ford Fusion Hybrid 2nd gen.jpg |name=Second generation |model_years=2013–present |production=2012–present |engine=2.0L Duratec 20 Hybrid [[Inline-four engine|I4]] |platform=[[Ford CD4 platform]] |transmission=ECVT (not a traditional CVT NO BELT), Ford HF35 (hybrid and PHEV) |battery = 1.4 [[kWh]] [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion]]{{cite web|url=http://cta.ornl.gov/vtmarketreport/spreadsheets/T33_Batteries_for_Selected_HEV_Vehicles_2013_2014.xls|title=Table 33. Batteries for Selected Hybrid-Electric Vehicles, Model Years 2013-2014|author=Josh Pihl|publisher=[[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]]|date=January 2014|accessdate=2014-11-21|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129052920/http://cta.ornl.gov/vtmarketreport/spreadsheets/T33_Batteries_for_Selected_HEV_Vehicles_2013_2014.xls|archivedate=November 29, 2014|df=mdy-all}} |wheelbase={{convert|112.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length={{convert|191.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|72.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height={{convert|58.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |related=[[Ford Mondeo]]
[[Lincoln MKZ]] }} A complete redesign of the Ford Fusion lineup for the [[model year]] 2013 was unveiled at the 2012 [[North American International Auto Show]]. The new lineup includes three optional engines for the conventional [[Inline-four engine|four-cylinder-only]] gasoline model, a next-generation hybrid version, and a [[plug-in hybrid]] version, the Ford Fusion Energi. The Ford Fusion became the first production sedan to offer these three powertrain options.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford.com/cars/fusion/2013/?searchid=|title=2013 Fusion|author=Ford|publisher=Ford|accessdate=June 10, 2012}} In April 2012 Ford announced that an auto [[start-stop system]] will be available for the 1.6-liter EcoBoost engine non-hybrid version, at a price of {{USD|295}}. The expected fuel economy was a combined {{convert|37|mpgUS|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/04/fordstopstart-20120402.html|title=Ford prices Auto Start-Stop system in non-hybrid 2013 Fusion 1.6L EcoBoost model at $295|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=April 2, 2012|accessdate=April 3, 2012}} Sales of the gasoline-powered and hybrid version began in the U.S. in October 2012.{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=37314|title=Ford C-MAX Hybrid Outsells Toyota Prius v in First Full Sales Month, Helps Ford Set Hybrid, Small Vehicle Sales Records|author=Ford Motor Company|publisher=Media Ford|date=November 2, 2012|accessdate=November 18, 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104190005/http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=37314|archivedate=November 4, 2012|df=mdy-all|author-link=Ford Motor Company}} Sales in Europe and Asia, under the [[Ford Mondeo]] name, were planned to start in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/01/ford-introduces-new-fusion-midsize-sedan-with-new-hybrid-and-energi-plug-in-hybrid-versions.html|title=Ford introduces new Fusion midsize sedan with new hybrid and Energi plug-in hybrid versions|author=Ford Press Release|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=January 9, 2012|accessdate=January 9, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/09/ford-adds-plug-in-hybrid-to-fusion-arsenal/?ref=automobiles|title=Ford Adds Plug-In Hybrid to Fusion Arsenal|author=Christopher Jensen|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 9, 2012|accessdate=January 9, 2012}} Ford began taking orders of the Mondeo Hybrid in Germany in August 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/neuwagen/handel/articles/455328/?cmp=nl-125|title=First Order für den neuen Ford Mondeo|language=German|trans-title=First Order for the new Ford Mondeo|author=Staff|work=KFZ-betrieb |date=2014-08-08|accessdate=2014-08-09}} Production of the Mondeo Hybrid began at Ford's [[Valencia]], Spain, plant in November 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/ford-mondeo-hybrid-now-in-eu-production/|title=Ford Mondeo Hybrid Now In EU Production|author=Philippe Crowe|publisher=HybridCars.com |date=2014-11-28|accessdate=2014-11-30}} The [[nickel–metal hydride battery|nickel-metal hydride batteries]] used in the hybrid first generation were replaced with [[lithium-ion batteries]]. The 2013 model year Fusion Hybrid is more fuel efficient than its predecessor, with a [[US Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) rating of {{convert|42|mpgus|abbr=on}} combined, {{convert|44|mpgus|abbr=on}} in city and {{convert|41|mpgus|abbr=on}} in highway driving.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34312&id=33083&id=31388&id=26405|title=Compare Side-by-Side: 2014/13 Ford Fusion Hybrid FWD - 2010/2012 Ford Fusion Hybrid FWD|publisher=www.fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U.S. Department of Energy]] and [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|accessdate=2014-06-17}} Initially, the second generation Fusion Hybrid was rated {{convert|47|mpgus|abbr=on}} with the same rating for combined/city/highway cycles. However, in June 2014 Ford announced that it was downgrading the EPA fuel economy ratings on six of its 2013 and 2014 model year vehicles, including all its C-Max, Fusion and [[Lincoln MKZ#Second generation (2013)|MKZ]] full hybrids and its two plug-in Energi models. The ratings were lowered after an error was discovered in the company's internal testing data. Ford is making a goodwill payments to around 200,000 customers affected by its mistake.{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/ford-downgrades-hybrid-model-mpg-ratings/|title=Ford Downgrades Hybrid Model MPG Ratings|author=Jeff Cobb|work=HybridCars.com |date=2014-06-12|accessdate=2014-06-17}}{{cite news|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2014/06/12/ford-lowers-mpg-ratings-on-six-vehicles/|title=Official: Ford lowers MPG ratings on six vehicles|author=Brandon Turkus|work=Autoblog.com|date=2014-06-12|accessdate=2014-06-17}} After the ratings were lowered the 2013/14 Fusion Hybrid still slightly outperforms the 2012/2014 [[Toyota Camry Hybrid]] LE by 1 mpg-US city and 2 mpg-US highway, and the Camry XLE by 4 mpg-US city and 3 mpg-US highway.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=32092&id=32093&id=33083|title=Compare Side-by-Side: 2012 Toyota Camry Hybrid LE - 2012 Toyota Camry Hybrid XLE - 2013 Ford Fusion Hybrid FWD |publisher=www.fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U.S. Department of Energy]] and [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|accessdate=2014-06-17}} [[File:Ford Fusion Hybrid Brazil 02 2014 PRG 03.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Fusion Hybrid]] The second generation hybrid has a powertrain with a 2.0-liter Atkinson-cycle inline-four – downsized from the 2.5-liter unit used in the first generation Fusion Hybrid. Total output is estimated at {{convert|185|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|130|ftlb|Nm|abbr=on|-1}}, running to the front wheels via an electronically controlled [[continuously variable transmission]].{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2012/01/09/2013-ford-fusion-debuts-along-with-47-mpg-fusion-hybrid-100-mpg/#continued|title=2013 Ford Fusion debuts along with 47-MPG Fusion Hybrid, 100-MPGe Fusion Energi|author=Steven J. Ewing|publisher=Autoblog Green|date=January 9, 2012|accessdate=January 9, 2012}} The lithium-ion battery pack saves weight and generates more power than previous NiMH batteries, and allows the second generation Fusion Hybrid to raise its maximum speed under electric-only power from {{convert|47|to|62|mph|abbr=on}}. The 2013 Fusion Hybrid includes driver assistance and technologies based on sensors, cameras and radar that enable the car to see and respond. Fusion can help drivers maintain proper lane position (Lane Keeping System); adjust vehicle speed to changing traffic conditions through adaptive cruise control; active park assist to help identify suitable parking spaces and help park; and [[Blind Spot Information System]] (BLIS) with [[cross-traffic alert]], which consists of sensors in both rear quarter-panels that are able to detect traffic in a driver's [[Blind spot (vehicle)|blind spot]], providing both audible and visual warnings if traffic unseen by the driver is detected. BLIS technology enables cross-traffic alert, even aiding drivers backing out of parking space where visibility is obstructed.{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/29/new-ford-fusion-will-warn-drivers-who-drift/?ref=automobiles|title=New Ford Fusion Will Warn Drivers Who Drift|author=Paul Stenquist|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 29, 2011|accessdate=January 9, 2012}} ===Lincoln MKZ Hybrid=== [[File:2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid -- 2012 NYIAS.JPG|thumb|The [[Lincoln MKZ#Second generation (2013)|2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid]] was unveiled at the 2012 [[New York International Auto Show]]]] During the 2012 North American International Auto Show Ford also unveiled the Lincoln MKZ [[concept car|concept model]].{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/10/mkz-concept-is-the-next-step-in-lincolns-reinvention/?emc=eta1 |title=MKZ Concept Is the Next Step in Lincoln's Reinvention |author=Jerry Garrett|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 10, 2012|accessdate=January 23, 2012}} Ford offers a hybrid option of the redesigned [[Lincoln MKZ#Second generation (2013)|2013 Lincoln MKZ]], and like the previous MKZ generation, the MKZ Hybrid is available for the same price as the non-hybrid model.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2012/10/16/lincoln-mkz-hybrid-rated-at-45-mpg-below-47-mpg-fusion-hybrid/|title=Lincoln MKZ Hybrid rated at 45 mpg, below 47-mpg Fusion Hybrid |author=Sebastian Blanco|publisher=Autoblog.com|date=October 16, 2012|accessdate=October 17, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/03/in-new-york-lincoln-mkz-makes-a-proposition/?emc=eta1|title=In New York, Lincoln MKZ Makes a Proposition |author=Tamara Warren|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 3, 2012|accessdate=April 4, 2012}} The EPA rated initially the 2013 MKZ Hybrid at {{convert|45|mpgus|abbr=on}} with the same rating for combined/city/highway cycles. After the ratings of six Ford models were downgraded in June 2014, the MKZ was the model with the largest fuel economy reduction, 7 mpg-US in city/highway combined. The revised EPA ratings of 2013/14 MKZ Hybrid are {{convert|38|mpgus|abbr=on}} combined, {{convert|38|mpgus|abbr=on}} in city and {{convert|37|mpgus|abbr=on}} in highway driving. Despite sharing the same powertrain, the 2013/14 MKZ Hybrid is rated 4 mpg-US combined less than its sibling the second generation [[Ford Fusion Hybrid#Second generation|Ford Fusion Hybrid]], and 6 mpg-US less in city driving.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34316&id=34312|title=Compare Side-by-Side: 2014 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid FWD - 2014 Ford Fusion Hybrid FWD |publisher=www.fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U.S. Department of Energy]] and [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|accessdate=2014-06-17}} ===Ford Mondeo Hybrid=== The Mondeo Hybrid shares the same powertrain of the Fusion Hybrid combining a 2.0-liter gasoline engine with an electric motor and 1.4 kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery. Under the [[New European Driving Cycle]] the Mondeo is rated at {{Convert|67.3|mpgimp|abbr=on}} in combined driving, and {{Convert|100.9|mpgimp|abbr=on}} for urban driving, with {{CO2}} emissions of 99 g/km. Ford set a pricing for the Mondeo Hybrid that is competitive with Mondeo diesel powertrain variants. Retail deliveries are scheduled to begin in the UK in December 2014 at a pricing starting at {{GBP|24,995}}. ===Controversy over fuel economy ratings=== {{update|section|date=July 2014}} In December 2012, [[Motor Trend]] reported that [[Consumer Reports]] and Green Car Reports have found that the 2013 [[Ford C-Max Hybrid]] and 2013 Ford Fusion Hybrid, which share the same powertrain, do not deliver their triple {{convert|47|mpgus|abbr=on}} EPA ratings in real-world use.{{cite news|url=http://wot.motortrend.com/we-hear-2013-ford-fusion-hybrid-2013-ford-c-max-hybrid-dont-achieve-epa-fuel-economy-ratings-300391.html#axzz2FqEZN68f|title=We Hear: 2013 Ford Fusion Hybrid, C-Max Hybrid Don't Achieve EPA Fuel-Economy Ratings|author= Jake Holmes|work=[[Motor Trend]]|date=December 4, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://news.consumerreports.org/cars/2012/12/video-tests-show-2013-ford-fusion-c-max-hybrids-dont-live-up-to-47-mpg-claims.html|title=Tests show Ford Fusion, C-Max hybrids don't live up to 47-mpg claims|author=Consumer Reports|publisher=[[Consumer Reports]]|date=December 6, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130414134501/http://news.consumerreports.org/cars/2012/12/video-tests-show-2013-ford-fusion-c-max-hybrids-dont-live-up-to-47-mpg-claims.html|archive-date=April 14, 2013|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1080580_ford-hybrids-fuel-economy-failing-to-live-up-to-epa-ratings|title=Ford Hybrids' Fuel Economy Failing To Live Up To EPA Ratings? |author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=November 20, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012}} After running both vehicles through Consumer Reports real-world tests, the magazine found that 2013 Fusion hybrid achieved a combined fuel economy average of {{convert|39|mpgus|abbr=on}}, with {{convert|35|and|41|mpgus|abbr=on}} for city and highway. Consumer Reports concluded that the overall fuel economy for the Fusion Hybrid is off by 8 mpg, representing a deviation of about 20%. The consumer magazine said that their overall fuel economy results are usually close to the EPA's combined-mpg estimate, and among current models tested, more than 80% fall within 2 mpg margin. The largest discrepancy the magazine has previously found was 7 and 6 mpg for the [[Toyota Prius c]] and the [[Toyota Prius (XW30)|Prius liftback/fastback]], respectively. A few days later the Environmental Protection Agency said it will review claims that two new Ford hybrid vehicles are not delivering the advertised 47 mpg. Linc Wehrly, Director of Light-duty Vehicle Center Compliance Division at EPA's National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] commented that hybrids have far more variability in miles per gallon than a conventional vehicle. Most vehicles' real-world gasoline mileage is less than the EPA sticker number, and can often be 20% less than the sticker number depending on speed, temperature and other factors. The EPA explained that with hybrids the gap is much wider, as high as a 30% drop.{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20121208/AUTO0102/212080368#ixzz2FwSbbWeI|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130122141818/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20121208/AUTO0102/212080368%23ixzz2FwSbbWeI|url-status=dead|title=EPA will review Ford C-Max, Fusion 47 mpg claims|author=David Shepardson and Karl Henkel|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=December 8, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012|archive-date=January 22, 2013}} Ford responded in a statement, saying that, "''Early C-MAX Hybrid and Fusion Hybrid customers praise the vehicles and report a range of fuel economy figures, including some reports above 47 mpg. This reinforces the fact that driving styles, driving conditions, and other factors can cause mileage to vary''."{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-ford-inflated-fuel-economy-20121206,0,1964927.story|title=Consumer Reports says Ford Fusion, C-Max don't achieve MPG claims |author=Jerry Hirsch|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=December 6, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012}} A Ford spokesman also said they followed EPA's test guidelines and the company is standing by the ratings as determined by the current testing protocols. Nevertheless, they are working closely with the agency to determine if any changes are needed for the industry relative to hybrid vehicle testing.{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20121214/AUTO0102/212140426#ixzz2FwWJSPE7|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130121123808/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20121214/AUTO0102/212140426%23ixzz2FwWJSPE7|url-status=dead|title=Ford stands behind fuel efficiency numbers for C-Max Hybrid|author=Karl Henkel|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=December 14, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012|archive-date=January 21, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/12/cmax-20121215.html|title=Ford's math on hybrid fuel economy; standing by the C-MAX EPA ratings, acknowledging large real-world variance|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=December 15, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2012}} In July 2013, Ford issued a voluntary software update for the 2013 model year Fusion, C-Max and MKZ Hybrid, that attempts to improve on the lower-than-expected MPG claims.{{cite press release |url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=38296 |title=Ford Further Improving On-Road Hybrid Fuel Economy and Hiring for Future, as Electrified Vehicle Share Quadruples |publisher=Ford |location=U.S. |date=July 16, 2013 |accessdate=July 24, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130720011120/http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=38296 |archivedate=July 20, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Some of the changes include: * Increasing the maximum pure electric speed from {{convert|62|to|85|mph|km/h|abbr=on|0}}, allowing increased use of electric-only mode on the highway * Optimizing the use of Active Grille Shutters to reduce aerodynamic drag under more driving and temperature conditions including cold weather, during air conditioner use and when the engine coolant temperature is higher * Reducing the electric fan speed as a function of coolant temperature to minimize the fan's energy consumption * Shortening engine warm-up time by up to 50 percent to enable electric-only driving and engine shutdown at stops sooner after cold starts * Optimizing the climate control system to minimize use of the air conditioning compressor and reduce the energy used in cold weather operation. In August 2013, and due to the criticism and after several lawsuits about the worse-than-expected fuel economy, Ford voluntarily lowered all three EPA ratings of the C-Max Hybrid and will pay about a rebate to some 32,000 C-Max owners. The revised fuel economy ratings for combined was lowered from to {{convert|47|to|45|mpgus|abbr=on}}. Ford has no plans to change the fuel economy ratings on the 2013 Fusion hybrid, because the company used the Fusion hybrid test to generate the fuel economy label for the C-Max Hybrid following EPA's rules.{{cite news|url=http://www.autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20130815/OEM05/130819953/ford-lowers-fuel-economy-rating-on-c-max-hybrid-to-43-mpg#axzz2c5j0FBiD|title=Ford lowers fuel economy rating on C-Max hybrid 8.5% to 43 mpg|author=Nick Bunkley, Bradford Wernle and Gabe Nelson|work=[[Automotive News]]|date=August 15, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2013}} ==Ford Fusion Energi== {{Infobox electric vehicle |name=Ford Fusion Energi |image=Ford Fusion Energi SEL with badge WAS 2012 0583.jpg |manufacturer=[[Ford Motor Company]] |production=January 2013—present |model_years=2013—present |class=[[Mid-size car]] |layout= |body_style=4-door [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] |engine= {{convert|141|hp|kW|abbr=on|disp=flip}} 2.0L [[Inline-four engine|I4]] gasoline |platform=[[Ford CD4 platform]] | motor = {{convert|118|hp|kW|abbr=on|disp=flip}} | battery = 7.6 [[kWh]] [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion]]{{cite news|url= http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2013-ford-fusion-energi-plug-in-hybrid-test-review |title=2013 Ford Fusion Energi Titanium Plug-In Hybrid|author=Jeff Sabatini |work=[[Car and Driver]]|date=June 2013|accessdate=2014-06-14}} |electric_range='''[[Model year|MY]] 2017'''

S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2014-06-12 |accessdate=2014-06-14}} | related =[[Ford C-Max Energi]] }} The Fusion Energi is a [[plug-in hybrid]] unveiled at the 2012 North American International Auto Show, and retail sales in the U.S. began in February 2013. Initially it was priced at {{USD|39,495}}, and in January 2014 the starting price was reduced to {{USD|35,525}}.{{cite web|url= http://insideevs.com/ford-fusion-energi-gets-a-4000-price-reduction-to-34700/ |title=Breaking: Ford Fusion Energi Gets A $4,000 Price Reduction To $34,700 |author=Jay Cole|publisher=InsideEVs.com |date=January 7, 2014|accessdate=January 7, 2014}} Due to the capacity of its battery pack, the Energi qualifies for a [[government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Federal government|federal tax credit]] up to {{USD|3,750}} and [[government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Other states|any applicable state and local incentives]].{{cite news|url= http://blog.caranddriver.com/2013-ford-fusion-energi-you-know-the-plug-in-hybrid-priced-at-39495/ |title=2013 Ford Fusion Energi (You Know, the Plug-In Hybrid) Priced at $39,495|author= Justin Berkowitz|work=[[Car and Driver]]|date=2012-11-20 |accessdate=2012-11-22}} Energi models purchased in or after 2010 are eligible for a $4,007 tax credit, which is based on the capacity of the battery used to fuel the vehicle.{{cite web|url = http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/taxphevb.shtml | title = Federal Tax Credits for Plug-in Hybrids | publisher = US Department of Energy}} The 2013 Fusion Energi is eligible for access to California's [[high-occupancy vehicle lanes]] (HOV) with a solo driver, and also for a {{USD|1,500}} California state tax rebate.{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-autos-ford-fusion-energi-carpool-lanes-20130221,0,2766014.story |title=Ford's Fusion Energi plug-in hybrid granted carpool-lane access|author=David Undercoffler|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2013-02-21 |accessdate=2013-02-26}} A refreshed 2017 Fusion Energi is scheduled to be released by mid-2016. In addition to a new fascia and other technological upgrades, the 2017 model year has more efficient electric motors, allowing the refreshed 2017 model year Fusion Energi to increase its all-electric range and to improve its EPA fuel economy ratings.{{cite web|url= http://insideevs.com/2017-ford-fusion-energi-gets-new-look-better-mpg-improved-electric-driving/ | title=2017 Ford Fusion Energi Gets New Look, Better MPG, Improved Electric Driving | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=2016-01-11| accessdate=2016-05-15}} {{As of|2016|12}}, over 43,700 units have been sold in North America, with 43,327 units delivered in the U.S.{{cite web|url= http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard/ |title=December 2013 Dashboard|author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates|date=2014-01-06 |accessdate=2014-01-07}}{{cite news|url= http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2014-dashboard/ |title=December 2014 Dashboard|author=Jeff Cobb|work=HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates|date=2015-01-06 |accessdate=2015-02-07}} and about 386 units in Canada.{{cite web|first=Matthew |last=Klippenstein|url= https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1dLFJwZVdvNLRpmZqPznlzz6PB9eHMe5b-bai_ddRsNg/edit#gid=25 |title=Canadian Plug-in Electric Vehicle Sales|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=February 2017 |accessdate=2017-02-21}} ''Estimated sales.'' ===Specifications and range=== The Fusion Energi uses the same non-turbo 2-liter 4-cylinder engine supplements as the 2013 Fusion Hybrid to assist the electric motor. The Energi has a 7.6 [[kWh]] [[lithium-ion battery]] that powers the {{convert|118|hp|kW|abbr=on|disp=flip}} [[electric motor]]. The plug-in hybrid delivers total horsepower of 195 (145 kW) with a fully charged battery and has an electric-only top speed of {{convert|85|mph|abbr=on}}, {{convert|23|mph|abbr=on}} more than the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]]. [[File:Ford Fusion Energi WAS 2017 1631.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Charging port of the 2017 Ford Fusion Energi]] The Fusion Energi, [[model year]]s 2013 through 2016, has an official EPA [[all-electric range]] of {{convert|20|mi|abbr=on}} and the total range with a full tank of gasoline and a fully charged battery is {{convert|550|mi|abbr=on}} according to the EPA.{{cite web|url= http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34089&id=33398&id=35277&id=36248 |title=Compare Side-by-Side - 2013/14/15/16 Ford Fusion Energi Plug-in Hybrid|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov |author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2016-05-13 |accessdate=2016-05-15}} The all-electric range of the refreshed 2017 model year Fusion Energi increases to {{convert|22|mi|abbr=on}}, and thanks to a better fuel economy, the total range increases to {{convert|610|mi|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url= https://insideevs.com/news/330549/refreshed-2017-fusion-energi-gets-range-bump-better-mpg/ | title=Refreshed 2017 Fusion Energi Gets Range Bump, Better MPG | first=Jay | last=Cole | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=2016-05-06| accessdate=2016-05-15}}{{cite web| url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=36248&id=37470 | title=Compare Side-by-Side - 2016/2017 Ford Fusion Energi Plug-in Hybrid | publisher=Fueleconomy.gov | author=[[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]] | date=2016-05-27 | accessdate=2016-05-27}} The EPA's 2015 edition of the "''Light-Duty Automotive Technology, Carbon Dioxide Emissions, and Fuel Economy Trends''" presents utility factors for plug-in hybrids to represent the percentage of miles that will be driven using electricity by an average driver, in electric only or blended modes. Both the Fusion and C-Max Energi models have a utility factor in EV mode of 45%, compared with 83% for the [[BMW i3 REx]], 66/65% for the [[Chevrolet Volt]]/[[Cadillac ELR]], 43% for the [[McLaren P1]], 37% for the [[BMW i8]], and 29% for the [[Toyota Prius PHV]].{{cite web|url=https://www3.epa.gov/fueleconomy/fetrends/1975-2015/420r15016.pdf |title=Light-Duty Automotive Technology, Carbon Dioxide Emissions, and Fuel Economy Trends: 1975 Through 2015 |publisher=EPA |author=U. S. Environmental Protection Agency |date=December 2015 |accessdate=2016-05-15 |url-status=dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160602082748/https://www3.epa.gov/fueleconomy/fetrends/1975-2015/420r15016.pdf |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |df=mdy |author-link=U. S. Environmental Protection Agency }} ''See Table 7.2 - MY 2015 Alternative Fuel Vehicle Powertrain and Range.'' [[File:Ford Fusion Energi WAS 2017 1651.jpg|thumb|The refreshed 2017 [[model year]] Fusion Energi improved its EPA rated fuel economy in [[all-electric mode]] to 97 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPG-e).]] [[File:Ford Fusion Energi WAS 2017 1637.jpg|thumb|Hybrid 2.0L gasoline powered-engine (left) and inverter system controller on top of the AC electric motor.]] In May 2016, Ford reported, based on data collected from more than 610 million miles (976 million km) logged by its electrified vehicles through its telematics system, that drivers of these vehicles run an average of {{convert|13,500|mi|abbr=on}} annually on their vehicles, with about half of those miles operating in all-electric mode. A break down of these figures show an average daily commute of {{convert|42|mi|abbr=on}} for Ford Energi plug-in hybrid drivers. Ford notes that with the enhanced electric range of the 2017 model year model, the average Fusion Energi commuter could go the entire day using no gasoline, if the car is fully charged both before leaving for work and before leaving for home. According to Ford data, currently most customers are likely charging their vehicles only at home.{{ cite web | url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2016/05/2060527-ford.html | title=2017 Ford Fusion Energi PHEV boosts total range to 610 miles | first=Mike | last=Millikin | publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] | date=2016-05-27 |accessdate=2016-05-27}} ===Fuel economy=== Initially, the EPA rated the Energi's combined city/highway [[fuel economy in automobiles|fuel economy]] in [[all-electric mode]] at 100 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPG-e) (2.4 L gasoline equivalent/100 km).{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=37343|title=Ford C-MAX Energi: Most Range, More Efficiency and Affordability Than Any Plug-in Hybrid|author=Ford Motor Company|publisher=Media Ford|date=2012-11-08|accessdate=2012-12-02|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111105635/http://media.ford.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=37343|archivedate=November 11, 2012|df=mdy-all}} ''EPA ratings in MPG-e for combine, city and highway cycles.'' Later, due to complaints from owners not achieving the sticker fuel economy, and following a technical review, the official EPA rating in EV mode was downgraded to 88 MPG-e ({{convert|88|mpgus|L/100km|abbr=on|disp=out|1}}). The Fusion Energi combined fuel economy equivalent is the same as the 2013 [[Ford C-Max Energi]].{{cite web|url= http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/phevsbs.shtml |title=New Plug-in Hybrids|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=January 17, 2013|accessdate=January 17, 2013}} In a similar way, in [[charge-sustaining|hybrid]] operation, initially the Energi had an EPA combined city/highway fuel economy of {{convert|43|mpgUS|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20121114/BUSINESS0102/121114059/Ford-readies-Fusion-Energi-plug-hybrid-debut-2013?odyssey=nav%7Chead|title=Ford readies Fusion Energi plug-in hybrid for debut in 2013|author=Mark Phelan|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=November 18, 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121127183236/http://www.freep.com/article/20121114/BUSINESS0102/121114059/Ford-readies-Fusion-Energi-plug-hybrid-debut-2013?odyssey=nav%7Chead|archivedate=November 27, 2012|df=mdy-all}} It was later downgraded by the EPA to {{convert|38|mpgUS|abbr=on}}. EPA's rating for combined EV/hybrid operation is 51 MPG-e (4.6 L gasoline equivalent/100 km), which allowed the Fusion Energi to rank at the time in sixth place, together with the C-Max Energi, among the top ten EPA-Rated Fuel Sippers since 1984.{{cite web|url= http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/topten.jsp |title=Fueleconomy.gov's Top Ten EPA-Rated Fuel Sippers (1984 to present) - All Years |publisher=fueleconomy.gov |author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2014-10-10 |accessdate=2014-10-11}} ''Excludes all-electric vehicles. Click on the tab "EPA Rated - All Years. The 2013-2014 Fusion/C-Max Energi has a combined electric/hybrid fuel economy of 51 MPG-e, 55 MPG-e in city and 46 MPG-e in highway.'' The refreshed 2017 model year Fusion Energi has an increased EPA rated fuel economy in [[all-electric mode]] to 97 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPG-e) ({{convert|97|mpgus|L/100km|abbr=on|disp=out|1}}) for combined city/highway driving, with an energy consumption of 35 kWh/100 mi. The EPA rating in hybrid operation rose to {{convert|42|mpgUS|abbr=on}}. A [[Police car#Response car (pursuit car)|police pursuit version]] achieves 38 mpg, whereas the regular Interceptor gets 18 mpg.{{cite web|url= https://www.wired.com/2017/04/fords-first-hybrid-cop-car-one-mean-green-machine/ |title=Ford's First Hybrid Cop Car Is One Mean, Green Machine|publisher=Wired |date=2017-04-10 |accessdate= 2017-05-06 }} ==Awards and recognitions== ===First generation=== * In April 2009, [[Kelley Blue Book]] included the 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid among its 2009 list of "Top 10 Green Cars".{{cite web|url=http://www.kbb.com/KBB/green-cars/articles.aspx?BlogPostId=1483&r=408452098257839700|title=KBB Green: Top 10 Green Cars for 2009|publisher=[[Kelley Blue Book]]|accessdate=May 1, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416050742/http://www.kbb.com/kbb/green-cars/articles.aspx?BlogPostId=1483|archivedate=April 16, 2010|df=mdy-all}} * The 2009 [[U.S. News & World Report]] car ranking for best affordable mid-size cars is led by the 2010 Mercury Milan Hybrid followed by the 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid. United States#Historical sales 1999-2011|hybrid sales]] for calendar year 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/news/december-2011-dashboard-sales-still-climbing-35093.html|title=December 2011 2012|df=mdy-all}} Fusion hybrid sales in 2012 increased 24.9% over 2011 sales, and hybrid models represented a 5.8% share of the 241,263 Fusion sold in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2011/01/ford-fusion-sales-figures.html |title=Ford Fusion Sales Figures |publisher=Good Car Bad Car|author=Timothy Cain |date=September 2013|accessdate=September 8, 2013}} ===2013=== The introduction of the redesigned 2013 [[model year]] Fusion, with a more fuel efficient second generation powertrain, resulted in increased sales of the hybrid version, and by August 2013, sales were up 275.2% over the same period in 2012. The Fusion Energi achieved record sales in August 2013. Also during this month, the Fusion Hybrid recorded its best sales month ever in [[Washington, D.C.]], [[San Francisco]] and [[Seattle]], and its second best-selling month in [[Los Angeles]], another key hybrid market. This rapid increase in sales contributed to Ford achieving its best August [[electric drive vehicle]] sales ever.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/august-2013-dashboard/|title=August 2013 Dashboard|author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates|date=2013-09-05|accessdate=2013-09-08}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/05/mi-ford-hybrid-sales-idUSnPNDE75054+1e0+PRN20130905|title=Ford Delivers Best August Hybrid Sales Ever with C-MAX Energi and Fusion Energi Achieving Record Sales|author=Ford Press Release|work=[[Reuters]]|date=2013-09-05|accessdate=2013-09-08|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107185341/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/05/mi-ford-hybrid-sales-idUSnPNDE75054+1e0+PRN20130905|archivedate=January 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The Fusion Hybrid sales increased 164.3% from 2012 and ended 2013 as the fourth top selling hybrid in the U.S. after the Prius liftback, the Prius c and the Toyota Camry Hybrid. The redesigned 2013 model year Lincoln MKZ hybrid also experienced somewhat stronger sales during 2013. In July 2013, Ford announced that for the 2014 model year MKZ hybrid it would increase the share of production allocated to the hybrid version, from 20% for the 2013 model year to 40% of the 2014 model year. The Lincoln MKZ Hybrid is popular among consumers in part because it has the same base price as the non-hybrid MKZ.{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20130719/AUTO0102/307170113/1148/auto01/Lincoln-double-production-MKZ-Hybrid|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130908160406/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20130719/AUTO0102/307170113/1148/auto01/Lincoln-double-production-MKZ-Hybrid|url-status=dead|archive-date=2013-09-08|title=Lincoln to double production of MKZ Hybrid|author=Karl Henkel|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=2013-07-19|accessdate=2013-09-08}} ===2014=== Sales of hybrid electric cars in the U.S. in 2014 declined 8.8% from 2013. Following the trend of the hybrid market, Fusion Hybrid sales were down 5.0% from 2013, and continued to rank as the fourth top selling hybrid in the U.S. Sales of Lincoln MKZ Hybrid continued its growth trend with sales up 34.3% from a year earlier. The American plug-in hybrid market in 2014 was up 13.1% from 2013, while combined sales of both of Ford's Energi models (Fusion and C-Max) increased by 50.9% despite the reduction of their fuel economy ratings. Sales of the Fusion Energi were up 89.7% from 2013 while C-Mx Energi sales were up only by 17.9%. [[File:Ford Fusion Hybrid WAS 2017 1650.jpg|thumb|Frontal view of the refreshed 2017 Ford Fusion Hybrid]] ===2015=== The American hybrid electric segment continued to decline in 2015, down 15% from 2014. Following the general U.S. trend, Fusion Hybrid sales were down 30.3% from 2014, and the Fusion continued to rank as the fourth top selling hybrid in the U.S. Sales of Lincoln MKZ Hybrid fell 16.2% from a year earlier. The American plug-in hybrid market in 2015 was up 5.8% from 2014, however, sales of the Fusion Energi were down 15.6% from 2014, and C-Mx Energi sales were down by 10.0%. The Fusion Energi ranked as the second top selling plug-in hybrid in the country after the [[Chevrolet Volt]], up from third place in 2014, and passing the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]]. ===2017=== In 2017, after a redesign which improved efficiency, Ford Fusion Hybrid sales surged by 70.8%, making it the number two selling hybrid car in America, after the Toyota Prius Liftback, which had 12.5% more sales. In contrast, the newly-released Prius Prime surged 745%, consuming all the growth in the PHEV market, and American PHEVs like the Fusion (-39.6%) and Chevy Volt (-17.7%) suffered steep declines as new PHEV models from Volvo, BMW, and Mercedes ate into American car sales. ===Total US sales=== Since 2009 a total of 356,534 units of the Fusion hybrid family, including the Energi plug-in hybrid, have been sold in the United States through December 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2015-dashboard/|title=December 2015 Dashboard|first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates|date=2016-01-06|accessdate=2016-03-19}}{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2016-dashboard/ |title= December 2016 Dashboard | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates | date=2017-01-05 |accessdate=2017-02-20}}{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/december-2017-dashboard/ |title= December 2017 Dashboard | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com and Baum & Associates | date=2018-01-04 |accessdate=2018-03-05}} U.S. sales by year for each model and the share of hybrids out of total model sales are shown in the following table: {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! colspan="9" align=center style="background-color: #ffdead;" |
