motor = | battery = 75.7-98.8 kWh | powerout = {{convert|190-342|kW|hp PS|0|abbr=on}} | sp = us }} The '''Ford Mustang Mach-E''' is an upcoming five-door [[Electric car|electric]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] produced by [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]].{{cite web |url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/ford-mustang-mach-e/ |title=2021 Ford Mustang Mach-E electric SUV officially revealed |website=[[CNET|Roadshow by CNET]] |last=Cole |first=Craig |date=November 17, 2019 |accessdate=November 17, 2019}} The vehicle was introduced on November 17, 2019, and is expected to go on sale in late 2020 as a 2021 model.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a29810295/2021-ford-mustang-mach-e-photos-info/ |title=2021 Ford Mustang Mach-E Will Please EV Fans, Perplex Mustang Loyalists |magazine=[[Car and Driver]] |last=Hoffman |first=Connor |date=November 17, 2019 |accessdate=November 17, 2019}} ==Overview== The Mach-E name is inspired by the [[Ford Mustang Mach 1|Mach 1]] variant of the [[Ford Mustang (first generation)|first-generation Mustang]]. Conventional door handles are absent on the Mustang Mach-E, and the vehicle instead features buttons that pop open the doors and a small door handle protruding from the front doors. Owners can use their smartphones as a key as well as a keypad built into the B-pillar. The interior has a wide dashboard and built-in soundbar; the dash is equipped with a vertically mounted {{convert|15.5|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} touchscreen infotainment system with a rotary dial fixed onto it. The majority of the car’s systems are controlled through the screen, which uses Ford's recent SYNC 4 operating system that can accept wireless updates. A {{convert|10.2|in|cm|abbr=on}} digital cluster for the driver is also featured, while the steering wheel retains a number of physical buttons.{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/transportation/2019/11/17/20967565/ford-mustang-mach-e-electric-suv-specs-price-la-auto-show-2019 |title=Ford's Mustang Mach-E is an electric SUV with up to 300 miles of range |website=[[The Verge]] |last=O'Kane |first=Sean |date=November 17, 2019 |accessdate=November 18, 2019}} The Mustang Mach-E is built on the Global Electrified 1 (GE1) platform which is a heavily reworked version of the C2 platform that is used on the [[Ford Focus#Fourth generation (2018–present)|fourth generation Focus]] and [[Ford Kuga#Third_generation (2019–present)|third generation Kuga]]/[[Ford Escape#Fourth generation (2020–present)|fourth generation Escape]]. The model will be launched with two battery pack sizes and three power outputs. The entry-level rear-wheel drive version is offered with either a 75.7 kWh battery producing 255 hp or a 98.8 kWh extended battery producing 282 hp. Both battery packs have a claimed 0-60 mph time of under seven seconds and an EPA range of around 230 and 300 miles respectively.{{cite web |url=https://jalopnik.com/a-look-at-the-engineering-behind-the-2021-ford-mustang-1839911078 |title=A Look At The Engineering Behind The 2021 Ford Mustang Mach-E |website=[[Jalopnik]] |last=Tracy |first=David |date=November 22, 2019|accessdate=November 27, 2019}} A dual-motor all-wheel-drive version is also offered with either the same 75.7 kWh battery producing 255 hp, or the 98.8 kWh extended battery producing 332 hp. Both versions have a claimed 0-60 mph time of under six seconds, with estimated EPA ranges of 210 and 270 miles. Charging is available via an AC home charger or DC fast chargers at up to 150 kW.{{Cite web|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/mustang-mach-e-reveal/|title=Ford Unveils All-Electric Mustang Mach-E|work=[[Digital Trends]]|last=Zurschmeide|first=Jeff|date=November 17, 2019|accessdate=November 18, 2019}} The car has a traditional cargo area at the rear with a claimed volume of {{convert|29|cuft|liter|0|abbr=on}}, and a {{convert|4.8|cuft|liter|0|abbr=on}} waterproof trunk under the hood.{{cite web |title=2021 Ford® Mustang Mach-E SUV {{!}} All-Electric & Exhilarating |url=https://www.ford.com/suvs/mach-e/2021/ |publisher=[[Ford Motor Company]] |accessdate=November 18, 2019 |language=en}} == Specifications == {| class="wikitable" |+Specifications {{Cite web|url=https://www.ford.com/buy/mach-e/build-and-price.html?config=WANAB-CGW-2021-CX727#/model|title=Ford Mach-E Build and Price |website=www.ford.com |publisher=Ford|language=en|access-date=2020-03-22 |url-status=live}}{{cite web |url=https://www.ford.com/cmslibs/content/dam/brand_ford/en_us/brand/suvs-crossovers/mache/3-2/pdf/seo-pdfs/Mustang_Mach-E_Tech_Specs-SEO.pdf|title=2021 Ford Mustang Mach-E Technical Specifications |website=[[ford.com]] |access-date=March 22, 2020}} !Battery ! colspan="4" |Standard Range (75.7kWh) ! colspan="10" |Extended Range (98.8 kWh) |- !'''Powertrain''' ! colspan="2" | RWD ! colspan="2" | AWD ! colspan="2" | RWD ! colspan="3" | AWD |- !Model ! (59.6 cuft including rear trunk + 4.8 cuft frunk) |} ==Marketing== Ford hired British actor [[Idris Elba]] (who once worked for [[Ford of Britain]] along with his father) to star in several teaser commercials for the car and host the Mustang Mach-E's official debut on November 17, 2019.{{cite web |url=https://www.motor1.com/news/380346/ford-idris-elba-mustang-ev/ |title=Ford Hires Idris Elba To Help Launch Mustang-Inspired EV Crossover |first=Christopher |last=Smith |website=[[Motorsport Network]] |date=November 4, 2019 |accessdate=November 18, 2019}}{{cite magazine |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a29685118/ford-idris-elba-electric-crossover/ |title=Ford and Idris Elba Partnering to Promote New Mustang-Inspired Electric Crossover |first=Connor |last=Hoffman |magazine=[[Car and Driver]] |date=November 4, 2019 |accessdate=November 18, 2019}} ==Production== Unlike the [[Internal combustion engine|ICE]] Mustang models, the Mach E will not be assembled in the United States. Rather, it will be produced in [[Cuautitlán Assembly|Cuautitlán Izcalli, Mexico]]. According to Ford CEO Jim Hackett, assembling the vehicle in Mexico will allow Ford to make a profit from the first vehicle, unlike other electric vehicles. He also stated that as Ford develops factory capacity for electric vehicle production in the United States, production could be moved there. The company is also considering production in China.{{cite web |url=https://business.financialpost.com/transportation/autos/ford-unveils-electric-mustang-suv-to-challenge-tesla-dominance |title=Ford bets Mustang Mach-E will be the electric that actually makes a profit |publisher=Postmedia |website=financialpost.com |date=November 18, 2019 |first=Keith |last=Naughton |agency=Bloomberg News}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.ford.com/suvs/mach-e/2021/}} ==See also== * [[Porsche Mission E Cross Turismo]] * [[Tesla Model X]] * [[Tesla Model Y]] * [[Jaguar I-Pace]] * [[Rivian R1S]] * [[Audi e-tron (2018)|Audi e-tron]] {{Ford Mustang}} {{Ford vehicles}} {{Modern North American Ford trucks}} [[Category:Ford vehicles|Mustang Mach-E]] [[Category:Battery electric cars in development]] [[Category:Crossover sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2019]]

The '''Ford Puma''' is a [[Subcompact car|subcompact]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover]] marketed by [[Ford of Europe|Ford Europe]].
==Specifications== The Puma is offered with a [[mild hybrid]] [[Ford EcoBoost engine#1.0 L Fox|1.0-liter EcoBoost 3-cylinder turbo gasoline engine]] with a belt-driven integrated starter, which uses energy from the braking system to charge the 48-volt lithium-ion battery pack in order to increase torque and lower emissions. Power is rated at {{convert|153|bhp|PS|abbr=on}} - 114 kW - and {{convert|240|Nm|lb.ft|abbr=on}} with an additional {{convert|50|Nm|lb.ft|abbr=on}} from the integrated starter system.
It is based on the seventh generation Fiesta chassis.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Allan |first1=Lawrence |title=Ford revives Puma name for "evocative" new small SUV {{!}} Autocar |url=https://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/ford-revives-puma-name-evocative-new-small-suv |accessdate=3 April 2019 |work=www.autocar.co.uk |date=3 April 2019}}</ref>
==Production== Production of the Puma started in [[Craiova]], [[Romania]] ([[Ford Romania]]) in October 2019 along with the [[Ford EcoSport|EcoSport]] subcompact crossover and the [[Ford EcoBoost engine#1.0 L Fox|EcoBoost 1.0 L Fox]] engine used in both cars.
Ford invested 200 million euros and employed 1,700 people on the project.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ford Begins Puma Production In Romania |url=https://industryeurope.com/ford-begins-puma-production-in-romania/ |accessdate=23 December 2019 |work=industryeurope.com |date=10 October 2019}}</ref>
The vehicle is only available in the European market.<ref name="Tiny Weird-looking"/>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="150px"> File:2019 Ford Puma ST-Line X First Edition EcoBoost Hybrid 1.0 Rear.jpg|Rear view File:Ford Puma (2019) at IAA 2019 IMG 0434.jpg|Interior </gallery>
==Name revival== Ford first announced the revived Puma nameplate, which was last used on the [[Ford Puma (sport compact)|Puma sport compact]], at its Go Further event in [[Amsterdam]], along with the introduction of the [[Ford Kuga#Third generation (2019–present)|third generation Kuga]].

'''USS ''Eagle 56'' (PE-56)''' was a [[United States Navy]] [[World War I]]–era [[patrol boat]] that remained in service through [[World War II]]. On 23 April 1945, while towing targets for U.S. Navy bomber exercises off the coast of [[Maine]], ''Eagle 56'' was sunk by the {{GS|U-853}}. Only 13 of the 62 crew survived. The loss was classified as a [[boiler]] explosion until 2001, when historical evidence convinced the US Navy to reclassify the sinking as a combat loss due to enemy action.
==Service history== ''Eagle 56'' was one of 60 {{sclass2-|Eagle|patrol craft}} built by [[Henry Ford]] late in World War I as [[submarine chaser]]s, none of which saw action. Unpopular due to their poor sea handling, only eight remained in service at the time of [[World War II]].<ref name="green">{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=6892|title= Navy Senior Archivist Helps Solve 57 Year Old USS Eagle 56 Mystery|author=Jack A. Green|publisher=navy.mil| accessdate=2007-10-07|date=25 April 2003}}</ref> ''Eagle 56'' was patrolling off the [[Delaware Capes]] in January 1942.<ref name="proceedings">Cianflone, Frank A. "The Eagle Boats of World War I" ''United States Naval Institute Proceedings'' June 1973 pp. 76–80</ref> ''Eagle 56'' remained almost constantly at sea during the [[Second Happy Time]]<ref name="proceedings"/> of the [[Battle of the Atlantic]], during which Axis submarines attacked merchant shipping along the east coast of North America. When her [[depth charge]]s were expended, a small ship from [[Cape May, New Jersey]], would bring out a new supply.<ref name="proceedings"/> ''Eagle 56'' rescued survivors of {{USS|Jacob Jones|DD-130|2}} off Cape May in February 1942.<ref name="proceedings"/> It was damaged by collision with the submerged wreck of ''Gypsum Prince'' while rescuing survivors from the British freighter that had collided with the British tanker ''Voco'' on 4 March at the entrance to Delaware Bay,<ref name="proceedings"/> and was repaired using parts from another ''Eagle'' boat, and then assigned to the [[Key West]] [[sonar]] school in May 1942.<ref name="proceedings"/>
===Sinking and investigation=== ''Eagle 56'' was assigned to [[Naval Air Station Brunswick]] from 28 June 1944.<ref name="proceedings"/> At noon on 23 April 1945, ''Eagle 56'' exploded amidships, and broke into two pieces<ref name="green"/> {{convert|3|mi|km|abbr=on}} off [[Cape Elizabeth, Maine]].<ref name="elizabeth">{{cite web|url=http://www.capeelizabeth.com/news/eaglememorial.html |title=Dedication of Navy warship marker set for Saturday at Portland Head Light |date=22 April 2005 |accessdate=2007-10-07 |publisher=capeelizabeth.com |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019105221/http://www.capeelizabeth.com/news/eaglememorial.html |archivedate=19 October 2006 }}</ref> The [[destroyer]] {{USS|Selfridge|DD-357|2}} was operating near ''Eagle 56'' and arrived 30 minutes after the explosion to rescue 13 survivors from the crew of 62.<ref name="proceedings"/> ''Selfridge'' obtained a sharp, well-defined sonar contact during the rescue and dropped nine Mark IX Mod 2 [[depth charge]]s without obvious result.<ref name="proceedings"/> According to a classified Navy report, {{GS|U-853||2}} had been operating in the waters off Maine.<ref name="green"/> At a [[Naval Board of Inquiry]] in [[Portland, Maine|Portland]] the following week, five of the 13 survivors claimed to have seen a submarine. Several spotted a red and yellow emblem on the submarine's [[Sail (submarine)|sail]].<ref name="holland">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollandsentinel.com/stories/090901/fea_0909010041.shtml |title=56 years later, Navy rewrites record |publisher=hollandsentinel.com |accessdate=2007-10-07 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050302093022/http://www.hollandsentinel.com/stories/090901/fea_0909010041.shtml |archivedate=2 March 2005 }}</ref> These insignia match the markings of ''U-853'': a red horse on a yellow shield.<ref name="green"/> ''Eagle 56''{{'}}s boiler was overhauled just two weeks before the sinking, and none of the boilers on the other 59 ''Eagle Boats'' had failed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tspweb02.tsp.utexas.edu/webarchive/08-30-01/2001083003_s03_New.html|title=Navy changes ship's records|date=30 August 2001|publisher=utexas.edu|accessdate=2007-10-07}}</ref> Nevertheless, the official Navy inquiry concluded that ''Eagle 56'' had suffered a boiler explosion.<ref name="green" />
==Later events== On 5 May 1945, ''U-853'' sank the [[Collier (ship type)|collier]] ''Black Point'' off the coast of [[Point Judith, Rhode Island]], causing the loss of 12 lives. During the ensuing [[German submarine U-853#Battle of Point Judith|Battle of Point Judith]], ''U-853'' was chased and sunk by Navy and [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] ships on 6 May.
On 1 June 1945, [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] [[Felix X. Gygax]] wrote, "at least equal evidence to support the conclusion that the explosion was that of a device outside the ship, the exact nature of which is undetermined. It might have been an enemy [[naval mine|mine]] or an enemy [[torpedo]]." Ultimately, though, he endorsed the court's findings.<ref name="holland"/>
Because the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] had [[Ultra|cracked Germany's codes]], United States intelligence knew in 1945 that U-boats had been sent across the [[Atlantic Ocean|North Atlantic]] to disrupt shipping in hopes of obtaining better surrender terms. However, only general warnings rather than specific information about this plan were passed to commanders.<ref name="boston"/>
===Reclassification=== [[file:Memorial USS Eagle-56.jpg|thumb|Plaque at Portland remembering the loss]] In 2001, the [[Naval Historical Center]] reviewed the case and reclassified the sinking as a combat loss. In June 2001, [[Purple Heart]] medals were awarded to three survivors and the next of kin of those killed.<ref name="green"/> As of 2007, this is the only time that the US Navy has overruled its own Court of Inquiry.<ref name="boston">{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2006/04/06/the_truth_about_the_uss_eagle_56/|title=The truth about the USS Eagle 56|author=Robert Knox|date=6 April 2006|publisher=boston.com|accessdate=2007-10-07}}</ref>
A commemorative plaque was erected on the grounds of [[Fort Williams Park]] near [[Portland Head Light]].
===Wreck discovery=== The ship's wreckage was located in June 2018, and visited by a civilian dive team later the same month. It lies {{convert|5|mi|km|spell=in}} off the coast of Maine at a depth of {{convert|300|ft|m}}.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Vigdor |first1=Neil |title=U.S. Navy Ship Sunk in World War II by German Sub Is Found Off Maine Coast |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/19/us/sunken-warship-discovered.html?action=click&module=Latest&pgtype=Homepage |accessdate=19 July 2019 |work=The New York Times |date=19 July 2019}}</ref> A video taken by the divers shows that USS ''Eagle 56''{{'}}s boilers are intact.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sharp |first1=David |title=Navy vessel sunk by German sub in WWII finally found |url=https://www.navytimes.com/news/your-navy/2019/07/18/navy-vessel-sunk-by-german-sub-in-wwii-finally-found/ |accessdate=19 July 2019 |work=Navy Times |date=19 July 2019}}</ref> The ship's steel plating is starting to rust away, but the site has been designated a [[war grave]], and it has all the protections associated with that designation.<ref>{{cite web|title=This Navy warship went down in World War II with 49 crew members aboard. Divers finally found it after 75 years|website=CNN|language=en|date=19 July 2019|author=Michelle Lou|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/this-navy-warship-went-down-in-world-war-ii-with-49-crew-members-aboard-divers-finally-found-it-after-75-years/ar-AAEx6Jr?ocid=spartanntp}}</ref>
